Question 72
ID: 304818
You have a Microsoft Fabric eventhouse named Eventhouse1 that contains high-velocity and high-volume data from IoT devices. Eventhouse1 can be queried to deliver data to reports in near-real-time (NRT). You plan to use Power BI Desktop to create a report that will contain both historical and live data. You need to connect to Eventhouse1. The solution must minimize development effort. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Build a composite model.
  • B. Use DirectQuery connectivity mode.
  • C. Use Import connectivity mode.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
9331415 Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Combines Import mode (for historical data) and DirectQuery (for live data)
a2c7cd3 Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
A is correct.
944e7a1 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Direct query is the EASIEST way to accomplish what is being asked. Historical data remains in the system so there is no need to import anything. Composite mode would definitely work but it is adding complexity. The answer should be B.
50e43b5 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
The simplest and fastest way to connect to Eventhouse1 and get NRT data in Power BI is: B. Use DirectQuery connectivity mode Even though A (composite model) is more robust for combining live + historical, B is the correct answer here, given the emphasis on minimizing development effort.
Dusica Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
I don't think there is additional dev effort for using composite mode. PQ will use each as per need.
c41d525 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Un mod√®le composite te permet de combiner plusieurs modes de connectivit√© dans un seul mod√®le Power BI : Importation pour les donn√©es historiques ‚Üí performances √©lev√©es, traitement rapide. DirectQuery pour les donn√©es r√©centes ou en quasi temps r√©el ‚Üí toujours √† jour, sans avoir besoin de recharger le mod√®le.
Question 73
ID: 148896
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have an on-premises data gateway. You need to reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models that run in Import storage mode. Solution: You create aggregations to summarize results. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
1CY1 Selected: B üëç 7 N/A
Create aggregations to summarize results. This seems to be saying group and summarize after the data has come through the gateway as an import. This will not reduce the traffic as it has already come through the gateway. Answer : B.No.
sroumi Selected: B üëç 4 N/A
Explanation Import Mode Behavior: When a model is set to Import mode, the complete dataset is loaded into Power BI‚Äôs in‚Äëmemory engine during refresh. The on‚Äëpremises data gateway is used only at refresh time to pull data from the on‚Äëpremises source. Once the data is imported, all queries run against the local in‚Äëmemory copy in the service, not through the gateway. Role of Aggregations: Aggregations are designed to improve query performance‚Äîespecially in composite models or DirectQuery scenarios‚Äîby pre‚Äëcalculating summarized data and reducing the need to hit detailed tables at query time. Why It Doesn‚Äôt Meet the Goal: In Import mode, even if you create aggregations, the full data refresh still occurs via the gateway. Aggregations do not affect how much data is transferred during a data refresh; they only reduce query processing time at runtime.
chicken_chaser Selected: B üëç 4 N/A
depends on where the aggregation is conducted. If it is done in power BI then the amount of data will still be the same. If the aggregation is done in the source then Yes
Odidepse Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Yes, creating aggregations to summarize results reduces the amount of data sent through the on-premises data gateway by summarizing the data in the semantic model. Creating aggregation reduce querying time and compression.
tko86 Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
It can't be B. If the data is imported and you then you aggregate (creating summarize tables) off the imported data, you are not reducing the overall model. You are actually increasing the size. While the summarize table would perform quicker, the original imported table with all the data remains. You need to reduce it at it's source before you bring in the data through import storage.
jaume Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Aggregations allow you to precompute and store summarized data, which minimizes the need to load and query large amounts of detailed data. This approach is particularly beneficial in large DirectQuery or Import models:
amiruladliroslibin üëç 3 N/A
not sure of question. you aggregate the results after importing? then the answer is no. if you are doing it before then the answer is yes
Dusica Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Again a bit of ambiguity. Gateway presumes database which may presume folding which means less load on gateway which means A
lmml_et Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
You create aggregations in Power Query before importing data, soy you reduce de amount of data in the semantic model and in the gateway
Lulu_2022 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Yes, this solution does meet the goal. Creating aggregations in your semantic model helps reduce the volume of data that needs to be processed and transferred through the on-premises data gateway, even when using Import mode. Here's why: Aggregations summarize detailed data into higher-level totals (e.g., by product, date, or region). When visuals or measures can be answered using the aggregated table, Power BI queries the smaller, summarized table instead of the full detailed one. This reduces the amount of data loaded and refreshed, which in turn minimizes the load on the gateway and improves performance. Even though aggregation awareness is more commonly associated with DirectQuery or composite models, it can still be beneficial in Import mode by reducing the size of the dataset and the refresh footprint.
Question 74
ID: 82470
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have a Power BI report that imports a date table and a sales table from an Azure SQL database data source. The sales table has the following date foreign keys: ‚úë Due Date ‚úë Order Date ‚úë Delivery Date You need to support the analysis of sales over time based on all the date foreign keys. Solution: From Power Query Editor, you rename the date query as Due Date. You reference the Due Date query twice to make the queries for Order Date and Delivery Date. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
junaid2107 üëç 135 N/A
I dont understand What micorsoft hopes to achieve with trick questions. If questions leave so much to the analysts assumptions then the questions isnt testing the candidates knowledge
legionairemax üëç 23 N/A
The answer is correct. However, I believe the alternate solution given is wrong. I would say that 3 relationships for each date respectively would be made from the Date table to the Sales table. One being active and the other two inactive. Thus, allowing to filter by a specific date column The solution suggested is not required, as the report does not require any output that involves all 3 dates. It requires only sales over one date column at a time. Moreover, being date tables, they can significantly increase the size of the model (considering that the table is sales related).
Elektrolite üëç 11 N/A
link, or gtfo
MoxieTT üëç 10 N/A
I keep reading "trick" questions when reading peoples' experiences recently of PL-300.
Igetmyrole üëç 7 N/A
B is the correct answer. No, this solution does not meet the goal of supporting the analysis of sales over time based on all the date foreign keys. Renaming the date query as "Due Date" and referencing it twice in Power Query Editor does not create relationships between the sales table and the date table based on the difference date foreign keys (Due Date, Order Date, and Delivery Date).
rgabage Selected: A üëç 4 N/A
A. This was in the learning path.
cs3122 üëç 4 N/A
100% agree. There is so much ambiguity in the questions, and can easily be interpreted ways.
Dsbuff Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
A is correct. ChatGPT's response: Creating separate queries in Power Query for each date (Due Date, Order Date, and Delivery Date) by referencing a base date query is a recommended way to deal with role-playing dimensions. This method involves creating separate date tables for each date role you need to analyze. In Power BI, each of these tables will be related to the sales table using the respective date foreign key. This approach allows for creating active relationships between the sales table and each of the date tables, which enables the use of these dates in filters, slicers, and visuals without the need for DAX measures to handle inactive relationships. It is a common and efficient way to support analysis by different date roles within the same model.
jaume Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
I think even referencing two queries to the first one is not ensuring the import of just a sample of the data, this only can be achieved by filtering the data in the query retrieving the data into our model. If first query is not set in the right way to get only sample of the data, other two queries would retrieve same dataset and it would be not just a sample. My vote here is for B.No
burto üëç 2 N/A
wouldnt it be that since they are imported datasets it would be more productive to use DAX to transform the data?

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point. Hot Area:
Explanation:
Box 1: a line - Incorrect: * not line and clustered column The Line and Clustered Column Chart is a combo charts that combines the Line chart and Column chart together in one visual. By combining these two visuals together, you can make a very quick comparison between two sets of measures. Box 2: anomaly detection - Anomaly detection helps you enhance your line charts by automatically detecting anomalies in your time series data. It also provides explanations for the anomalies to help with root cause analysis. With just a couple of clicks, you can easily find insights without slicing and dicing the data. Example: Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/visuals/power-bi-visualization-anomaly-detection

Question 77
ID: 304984
You have a Power BI report named Report that contains the following tables. For the last three days, refresh in Power BI has failed, and you receive the following error message: ‚ÄúYou have reached the maximum allowable memory allocation for your tier. Consider upgrading to a tier with more available memory.‚Äù You need to resolve the error and ensure that query response times are minimized for end users. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Merge the Sales person and invoice tables based on the SalesPersonId column.
  • B. Change the invoice table to a DirectQuery table and read the data live from the source, retaining only the dimension tables as import tables.
  • C. Reduce the size of the invoice table by summarizing sales by Product, Sales person, Calendar, and Customer.
  • D. Change the invoice table to a composite table that contains historical data as a DirectQuery table and hot data as an import table, and then partition the table.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
Lulu_2022 Selected: D üëç 6 N/A
- Keeps ‚Äúhot‚Äù recent data (e.g. last 30 days) fast with import mode - Pushes bulk historical data (e.g. older than 6 months) to DirectQuery - Memory load drops, and the most viewed data stays performant - Partitioning lets you manage refresh logic smartly and incrementally
PhoebeZ Selected: C üëç 4 N/A
here is what Gemini says: The feature in Option D is designed for fact tables that have a long history of data (e.g., many years of transactions). It works by partitioning the table so that recent, "hot" data is imported for fast performance, while older, "cold" data is left in DirectQuery mode to save memory. The problem in the question states that the Invoice table already only contains data from the "last three months." There is no older, historical data to partition off into DirectQuery mode. The entire 12-million-row table is considered "hot" data. Therefore, since the recent data itself is too large, the correct solution is C (summarizing the data). This directly reduces the number of rows within that three-month period, which solves the memory issue.
13a8051 Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
I just posted in favor of C, but what if the last three months data is considered the "cold" data, and the "last three days" data is the hot data? Then D would work, too. Last three days = hot data (imported for fast queries) Earlier part of the three months = cold data (kept in DirectQuery to save memory) Then Option D works well because you still get the benefits of partitioning and composite mode, even though the overall data is recent. The nuance makes the difference.
13a8051 Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
C is the correct answer. Option D‚Äôs composite model with partitioning is ideal when you have a large fact table spanning many years, so you can separate ‚Äúhot‚Äù recent data (imported) from ‚Äúcold‚Äù historical data (DirectQuery). But the question says the Invoice table only has data for the last three months ‚Äî all of it ‚Äúhot‚Äù data that can‚Äôt be partitioned into historical vs recent. So composite mode and partitioning won‚Äôt reduce the memory needed. Therefore, the entire dataset is too large to fit in memory, and you need to reduce the size itself. Option C (summarizing sales by Product, Sales person, Calendar, Customer) reduces the number of rows significantly by aggregating, which lowers memory usage and fits your tier‚Äôs limits. This also helps maintain acceptable query performance because the table is smaller and pre-aggregated.
omath Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: D. Change the invoice table to a composite table that contains historical data as a DirectQuery table and hot data as an import table, and then partition the table. * Explanation: - The error indicates memory limits are exceeded during refresh because the Invoice table has 12 million rows. - A composite model with Import for hot data (recent months) and DirectQuery for historical data reduces memory usage while keeping recent data fast for end users. - Partitioning ensures efficient refresh and query performance. * Why not the others: - A. Merge Sales person and Invoice: Increases table size and complexity, worsening memory issues. - B. Change Invoice to DirectQuery only: Reduces memory but can hurt performance for all queries. - C. Summarize Invoice: Loses detail needed for granular analysis.
Question 78
ID: 304851
HOTSPOT - You have a query that contains customer data in Power Query Editor as shown in the following exhibit. Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
c42611c üëç 4 N/A
1. Customer Name 2. Extract the last 12 characters -Customer Name because it has a greater number of distinct vs unique values in the column. This implies that there are repeating values in it. -Second statement requires 10 digits in the phone number. If choose "extract the text after the ")" delimiter", it will leave a leading whitespace for certain rows since there is a space after the ")" in certain rows and this counts as a digit which would make it 11 digits which does NOT meet the requirement. BUT, if we use the other option "Extract the last 12 characters", then it will NOT include the leading whitespace and correctly satisfy the 10 digit requirement as well as not including whitespace which can throw off calculations, sort orders, etc.
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: - Some values in the [answer choice] column are repeated: Customer Name (Distinct = 8,390 vs Unique = 8,175 indicates duplicates in names.) - To standardize the values in the Phone column to 10 digits and exclude country calling codes: extract the text after the ‚Äú)‚Äù delimiter (This removes the country code portion before the closing parenthesis.)
bp_a_user üëç 1 N/A
correct!
Question 79
ID: 304847
You use Power BI Desktop to create a report named RPT1 that loads data from a Microsoft Excel file named File1. File1 is located in a network share. File1 is moved to a different folder. When you open RPT1 in Power BI Desktop, you discover that the report displays outdated data. You need to ensure that the data in File1 refreshes properly. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Change the data source.
  • B. Clear the permissions of File1.
  • C. Export a PBIDS file.
  • D. Modify the permissions for File1.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
13a8051 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Change the data source. Btw, here‚Äôs why Power BI might show outdated data instead of an error when the source file is moved: When Power BI Desktop can‚Äôt find the source file at the original location, it doesn‚Äôt always throw a clear error immediately. Instead, it keeps showing the last loaded data cached inside the PBIX file. This cached data remains visible until you refresh the dataset and the refresh fails. If you open the report but don‚Äôt refresh, you‚Äôll just see the stale data from the previous load. So, to fix this, you still need to change the data source path to point to the file‚Äôs new location, then refresh to load the updated data. Otherwise, Power BI will keep showing the old data cached inside the report.
225401f Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
I think it is A
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. Change the data source. * Explanation: - When File1 is moved to a different folder, the original file path stored in the report becomes invalid. - To refresh data properly, you need to update the file path in Power BI Desktop by changing the data source settings to point to the new location. * Why not the others: - B. Clear the permissions of File1: This affects authentication, not the file path. - C. Export a PBIDS file: PBIDS helps share connection info, not fix broken paths. - D. Modify the permissions for File1: Permissions are not the issue; the path changed.
13a8051 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
A. Change the data source. Because the file moved folders, you need to update the data source path in Power BI Desktop to point to the new location.
Question 80
ID: 156372
You need to create a semantic model in Power BI Desktop. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ The model must contain a table named Orders that has one row per order. Each row will contain the total amount per order. ‚Ä¢ The orders must be filtered to the selected CustomerID value. ‚Ä¢ Users must select the CustomerID value from a list. ‚Ä¢ The list of customers must come from an OData source. Which three objects should you create in Power Query Editor? Each correct answer presents part of the solution. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Options

  • A. an Orders query that has a filter on CustomerID
  • B. a Customers query that has a filter on CustomerID
  • C. an Orders query that has a single column containing a list of customers
  • D. a Customers query that has a single column containing a list of customer IDs
  • E. a parameter for CustomerID that uses a query to populate the suggested values
  • F. a parameter for CustomerID that uses manually entered values to populate the suggested values

Answer

Suggested Answer:
ADE
SushiPowerBI_175 Selected: ADE üëç 5 N/A
A. an Orders query that has a filter on CustomerID This ensures the Orders table only includes rows related to the selected CustomerID. D. a Customers query that has a single column containing a list of customer IDs This query will provide the source for the list of selectable CustomerIDs, and it's coming from an OData source as per the requirement. E. a parameter for CustomerID that uses a query to populate the suggested values This parameter enables users to select a CustomerID from a dynamic list, which aligns with the requirement to select the value from a list and to link it with the Customers query.
8578db1 Selected: ADE üëç 2 N/A
A. only orders query that satisfies requirements D. Customers Query only exists to give a filter. E. Param needs to be drop down, not manually entered.
omath Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A, D, and E - A. An Orders query that has a filter on CustomerID (driven by the parameter). - D. A Customers query that has a single column containing a list of customer IDs (from the OData source). - E. A parameter for CustomerID that uses a query to populate the suggested values (bind it to the Customers query column).
Dusica Selected: ADF üëç 1 N/A
E is fine in online query editor. Query/list is not available in desktop for parameters
13a8051 Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
Selected: A: Filter Orders by CustomerID to get one row per order for the selected customer. D: Get a list of CustomerIDs from the OData source to feed the parameter. E: Create a parameter for CustomerID whose suggested values come from the Customers query (dynamic list). Not selected: B: Don‚Äôt filter Customers ‚Äî you need the full list to populate the parameter. C: Orders shouldn‚Äôt hold customer lists ‚Äî that belongs in the Customers query. F: Manual values don‚Äôt meet the requirement for a dynamic list from OData.
lechuc508 Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
A. an Orders query that has a filter on CustomerID D. a Customers query that has a single column containing a list of customer IDs E. a parameter for CustomerID that uses a query to populate the suggested values
Question 81
ID: 156301
You plan to create a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that will contain data from an Azure SQL database named DB1. Model1 must show updated data within two minutes of the data being updated in DB1. You need to select a connectivity mode for the connection to DB1. What should you choose?

Options

  • A. DirectQuery
  • B. live connection
  • C. import

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Minh2712 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
DirectQuery, as the model requires near real-time refresh.
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. DirectQuery * Explanation: - DirectQuery keeps the data in the source (Azure SQL DB) and queries it in real time. - It supports near real-time updates because Power BI retrieves data directly from the database whenever the report is refreshed or interacted with. - This meets the requirement of showing updated data within two minutes of changes in DB1. * Why not the others: - Live connection: Used for Analysis Services models, not for Azure SQL DB. - Import: Loads data into Power BI‚Äôs in-memory model; updates require scheduled refresh, which cannot guarantee a 2-minute latency.
13a8051 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
The correct answer is A. DirectQuery ‚úÖ Reason: DirectQuery mode keeps data in the source system (DB1 in this case) and queries it in real time (or near real time) whenever a user interacts with a report. This means Model1 will reflect updates from DB1 within minutes ‚Äî depending on refresh policy and query performance, even instantly. Why not the others? Live connection ‚Äì Only applies to connecting to existing Analysis Services or Power BI datasets, not directly to Azure SQL Database. Import ‚Äì Data is copied into Power BI‚Äôs in-memory model and only updates when you refresh it. Even with scheduled refresh, the minimum is usually every 30 minutes (in Premium workspaces) ‚Äî not 2 minutes. DirectQuery is the only option here that meets the within two minutes requirement.
Nadja_nghol Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Live connection mode allows you to connect directly to an Analysis Services model, either in Azure Analysis Services or SQL Server Analysis Services, it's not this case; because of the refresh short time the correct answer is 'DirectQuery
Anloindian123 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
DirectQuery is best. 2 minutes is very close to real-time
Pitxunet Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
It seems the most appropriate solution for having the data updated all the time. No point in using import if we need to refresh the model every two minutes
Question 82
ID: 156777
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model. You discover that the semantic model contains values that display as errors. You need to use data profiling features in Power Query to preview the data and identify the issues. What should you select to gain insight into the number of errors in the model, and what should you select to resolve the errors? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct answer is worth one point.
Zander3 üëç 4 N/A
"Column quality" is what helps us gain insight because it shows the number of valid values, errors, and empty values in a column. For resolution, "Replace errors" would actually allow us to fix those errors, unlike options like "Remove duplicates" or "Remove empty," which don‚Äôt actually address the errors themselves.
13a8051 üëç 1 N/A
1. To gain insight into the number of errors: ‚úÖ Column Quality In Power Query, turn on Column Quality (from the View tab). This displays a bar showing the percentage of Valid, Error, and Empty values for each column, so you can quickly see how many errors you have. 2. To resolve the errors: ‚úÖ Remove Errors Right-click the column with errors ‚Üí Remove Errors to filter out all error rows. Or, if you want to fix instead of remove, you could also use Replace Errors with default values. Final Answer: Gain insight: Column Quality Resolve errors: Remove Errors
BhavnishM üëç 1 N/A
both column quality and column profile are used to analyze errors. Since , column profile is not the an option, column quality is right.
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: To gain insight: Column Quality (it shows percentages of valid, error, and empty values). To resolve the errors: Replace Errors (we can replace error values with defaults or correct values).
Mi4as üëç 1 N/A
"Replace error" is correct, but the first block doesn't have any useful option. "Column distribution" shows distinct/unique count - not help at all, and if we have an error(our case) it shows nothing. "Column quality" shows the per cent valid/error/empty. OK, we have 52% of errors and what? What we really need here that the "Column profile" which shows all the information to identify the scope of error and replace errors.
Question 83
ID: 156070
You have a Microsoft Power BI Desktop report named Report1 that uses an Azure SQL database as a data source. A user named User1 plans to create a report by using the same data source as Report1. You need to simplify the connection to the data source for User1. Which type of file should you create?

Options

  • A. PBIDS
  • B. XLSX
  • C. PBIT
  • D. PBIX

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Oleh777 Selected: A üëç 12 N/A
Answer: A. PBIDS A .pbids (Power BI data source) file is specifically designed to simplify connections to a data source. If the user double-clicks the .pbids file, Power BI Desktop opens and automatically connects them to the specified data source‚Äîmaking it easy for someone else (User1) to reuse the same Azure SQL connection as in Report1.
13a8051 Selected: A üëç 4 N/A
The correct answer is A. PBIDS ‚úÖ Reason: A PBIDS file (Power BI Data Source file) is specifically designed to store data source connection information. When User1 opens it in Power BI Desktop, it automatically launches the ‚ÄúGet Data‚Äù experience with the connection details pre-filled ‚Äî so they just enter credentials and connect. Why not the others? XLSX ‚Äì Excel file, irrelevant here. PBIT ‚Äì Power BI Template file (stores model, queries, visuals, but not the actual data). Good for sharing a report structure, but overkill if you just want to share the connection. PBIX ‚Äì Full Power BI report file (data + visuals). That would give User1 your actual report, not just the connection info.
Bildey Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A PBIDS file is specifically designed to simplify the connection to a data source in Power BI.
a8d510b Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Answer is A
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. PBIDS * Explanation: - A PBIDS (Power BI Data Source) file stores the connection information for a data source. - When User1 opens the PBIDS file in Power BI Desktop, it automatically connects to the same Azure SQL database, simplifying the setup. - It does not include the data model or visuals‚Äîjust the connection details. * Why not the others: - XLSX: Excel file, unrelated to Power BI connection setup. - PBIT: Power BI template file (includes model structure and queries, but not data). Useful for sharing report templates, not just connection info. - PBIX: Full Power BI report file (includes data, visuals, and model). Overkill if the goal is only to simplify the connection.
Question 84
ID: 156397
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that contains a table named Sales. Sales contains 10 million records and the following data. The related report displays the weekly sales per region. You need to minimize the size of Model1. How should you modify the CustomerID column and the PurchaseDateTime column? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
BhavnishM üëç 6 N/A
just a short explanation on the answer: to minimize data size you should remove unnecessary columns, since you don't need customer id it is removed storing datetime timezone data type data takes more storage space than splitting it into 2 components and storing it as date and time.
Zander3 üëç 5 N/A
Since the report only displays weekly sales per region and doesn't require customer-level detail, you can remove the CustomerID column entirely to reduce model size. For the PurchaseDateTime column, splitting it into separate Date and Time columns lets you keep only the date portion (if that's all that's needed for weekly grouping), thereby minimizing unnecessary data.
4b88f2d üëç 3 N/A
Remove column / Split
e5accfd üëç 2 N/A
Remove the column and split. Answers are correct. The purpose of the related report is to recognize weekly sales so removing Customer ID wouldn't impact the report, but you do need Order ID to recognize the revenue in the right period, which leads to second part, you only need dates to recognize the sales in the appropriate week, I would split the Date column then delete the time column
Fellow_Commentor üëç 2 N/A
Removing Duplicate customer IDs will remove crucial data from the Table, since the same customer can have multiple purchases in the same region. The unique value here is Purchase ID not customer ID. At the same time, we do not know the nature of the content of the customer id field so we cannot convert it to binary either. So the only Option left is removing the column Customer ID altogether.
nebeskijahac üëç 2 N/A
should be: - remove the column - change the data type to Duration (this data type requires less space)
Pitxunet üëç 1 N/A
It can only be the suggested answer.
nebeskijahac üëç 1 N/A
How does splitting the column into separate date and time columns reduce the model size?
4b88f2d üëç 1 N/A
You can't remove duplicates from a Columna who has only unique values as is CustomerID. So is remove columns for me. And spliting is the only answer with sense in the second part.
Mi4as üëç 1 N/A
DateTime columns have high cardinality because each unique timestamp is treated as a distinct value. By splitting the column, you reduce the number of unique values in each column, which lowers cardinality and improves compression.
Question 85
ID: 156300
HOTSPOT - You are using Microsoft Power BI Desktop to profile data in Power Query Editor. Table data is displayed as shown in the following exhibit. Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Pitxunet üëç 30 N/A
In both cases you need to change the data type first
Mi4as üëç 3 N/A
Completely wrong options for answers, and no one gave the result = day number. We can do this in a step: = Table.TransformColumns(#"Changed Type",{{"Date.Entries.menuAmount", Date.Day, Int64.Type}}) So just click RM - transform - Day - Day = done, and you will get day number and Integer data type in one GO. First block: A) Change datatype. I tried to do that and any manipulation didn't return the date as datetype or day from the error value. B) Parse we don't have it under the column. This is available only for text datatype (we have date datatype) or for xml/json file (under transformation tabe - not a column menu). C) Replace Value - not a Replace Error. The second block either hasn't suitable option.
Zander3 üëç 2 N/A
Date column -Use the Parse command on the column-The parse command takes a text string and breaks it down into structured parts. If a column contains concatenated values, text with delimiters, you would use the Parse to split or extract the specific components you need for analysis. data.Entries.menu.Amount column- Change data type-In Power BI, the date value "01/01/1900" represents a zero value. To fix this, change the data type to a numeric type (such as Decimal Number or Whole Number). This adjustment should display the correct amounts and eliminate the errors.
Lulu_2022 üëç 2 N/A
1) Before transforming a column to show only the day, you must ‚Ä¢ Power BI needs the column to be in Date/Time format to enable any kind of date-specific transformation (like extracting day, month, year). 2) To fix errors in the menuAmount column, which contains data entry issues: Change the data type ‚Ä¢ Most common cause of errors in numeric columns is incorrect or inconsistent typing (e.g. text or nulls in a number column).

change the data type forr two questions
larahm üëç 1 N/A

langarz üëç 1 N/A
Power Query (M language) does not have a built-in PARSE function like in SQL or DAX
12cad83 üëç 1 N/A
Before you can transform the date column to show only the day, you must: change the data type. (Set the column to Date first; the Day transform is only enabled for Date-type columns.) To fix the error in data.Entries.menuAmount, you must: change the data type. (The column‚Äôs current type doesn‚Äôt match its values‚Äîe.g., dates showing as text or another type‚Äîso set the correct data type to eliminate the type error.) So the answer for both the sections is "Change the Data Type"
omath üëç 1 N/A
Before you can transform the date column to show only the day, you must: - change the data type (to Date). To fix the error displayed for the data.Entries.menuAmount column, you must: - change the data type (to the correct type, likely Decimal or Whole Number).

Question 86
ID: 154144
You use Power BI Desktop to import two tables named Customer and Contacts. The Customer table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Customer_Name ‚Ä¢ Customer ID ‚Ä¢ Website The Contacts table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Contact ID ‚Ä¢ Contact Email ‚Ä¢ Contact Name ‚Ä¢ Customer Name A web-based contact form is used to fill the Contacts table. The data is not sanitized. You need to create a merge for the Customer and Contacts tables. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Disable fuzzy matching.
  • B. Enable fuzzy matching.
  • C. Set Join Kind to Left Outer.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
NyashaDuri Selected: B üëç 24 N/A
First Why enable fuzzy matching? Since it says the Contacts table is filled using a web-based form without data sanitisation, there may be inconsistencies in how customer names are entered. Fuzzy matching will help match similar strings, accommodating for typos, capitalisation differences, and other minor variations in the customer names. "No confusion, and no need to discuss further" /s jk feedback welcome especially where I might be mistaken
Zander3 Selected: B üëç 5 N/A
Because the Contacts table is populated via a web-based form and the data isn't sanitized, you may encounter typos or formatting differences in the "Customer Name" field. Enabling fuzzy matching allows the merge to identify similar entries even if they're not an exact match, ensuring a more accurate join between the Customer and Contacts tables.
21ad543 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
"Data is not sanitized." = Enable Fuzzy Matching
omath Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: - B. Enable fuzzy matching. * Explanation: - The Contacts table uses a web-based form and the data is not sanitized, meaning the Customer Name values may have typos, inconsistent casing, or extra spaces. - A standard merge (exact match) would fail for these variations. - Fuzzy matching in Power Query allows approximate matches between text values, which is ideal for this scenario. * Why not the others: - A. Disable fuzzy matching: This would require exact matches, which is not suitable for unsanitized data. - C. Set Join Kind to Left Outer: This controls which rows are included after the merge, but does not solve the issue of inconsistent names.
Question 87
ID: 148529
HOTSPOT - You are designing the data model for a Power BI semantic model. You have the following tables in the star schema. Which table is the fact table of the star schema, and which column in the Patient table is the surrogate key of the star schema? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
b2775a4 üëç 7 N/A
Fact Table: Test Result Surrogate Key in Patient Table: Patient Key The fact table is the central table in a star schema and contains measurable data (e.g., metrics, values) and foreign keys to connect to dimension tables. The Test Result table is the fact table because: It contains measurable data like "result value." It includes foreign keys to dimensions like date, test key, and patient key. A surrogate key is a unique identifier for a row in a table, typically used as the primary key in star schemas. The Patient Key is explicitly stated as the unique identifier for rows, making it the surrogate key.
kenyJen üëç 4 N/A
Given anwsers are correct.
1CY1 üëç 4 N/A
Given answer is what I thought as well. Ans : D, C
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: - Fact table: Test Result This table records each administered test (transactional data), making it the central fact table in the star schema. - Surrogate key in Patient table: Patient key This is the unique identifier for each patient and is used as a foreign key in the fact table.
Onketsu üëç 1 N/A
D and C Fact tables contain the content of the data warehouse and store different types of measures like additive, non-additive, and semi-additive measures. Fact tables provide the (usually) additive values that act as independent variables by which dimensional attributes are analyzed.
Question 88
ID: 147044
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have a data source that contains a column. The column contains case sensitive data. You have a Power BI semantic model in DirectQuery mode. You connect to the model and discover that it contains undefined values and errors. You need to resolve the issue. Solution: You add an index key and normalize casing in the data source. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Tex02 üëç 13 N/A
I think the answer is A. adding the index key won't fix the problem by itself but you are also normalising the case which will resolve it.
dpkamalarani üëç 6 N/A
A is right
Sohang51 üëç 4 N/A
Actually i dont understand that how normalising the case will resolve the issue as undefined values and errors can also be related to missing values and unmatched data type..?
shreejoshi Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Adding index will not affect other column value or it's type. so error will remain the same.
kbcity1 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
The answer is B, adding an index key and normalizing casing in the data source does not resolve the issue of undefined values and errors in the Power BI semantic model in DirectQuery mode.
Andrew_17 üëç 2 N/A
Case sensitive data was resolved in data source
e9747cd Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
No, this solution does not fully meet the goal, because adding an index key does not resolve errors caused by case-sensitive data. Normalizing casing helps, but the index key is not relevant in this context.
f133b89 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Yes, this solution meets the goal.
leela1507 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Answer A
12cad83 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Yes. Normalizing the casing at the source (e.g., forcing all keys/text to upper/lower) removes case‚Äêsensitivity mismatches that cause blanks/undefined categories and join errors in DirectQuery. Adding a stable index/surrogate key also prevents collisions where two values differ only by case. Together, these fixes resolve the undefined values/errors without relying on Power BI transformations that are brittle in DirectQuery.

buddy you will not be able to see the meta data if you don't expand the attribute
INDEAVR üëç 12 N/A
I tested it. The correct answer is 1) Folder 2) Expand the Attribute column. I tested with Deleting the Content column and without deleting it, in both cases the content is not visible when you load the data in Power BI Desktop. In order to see the full metadata you should expand the Attributes column.
PD_Ve üëç 5 N/A
In the video, the author explains the answer to 2 different questions: the first question requires the steps to store the metada, in which case, the solution is folder/expand the atributes column. The second question requires the steps to store the data, in which case your answer it is the correct one. For the purpose of the question on discussion, the correct answer, according to the video is folder/expand atribute column.
agelee üëç 4 N/A
I tested and the correct option is to "Expand the Attribute column". The "Content" column is automatically removed when we close the PowerQuery. But if we don't click "Expand the Attribute column" we loose these information.

The defaut time out is 10 minutes, but if it takes more than it you can enter another value in minutes to keep the connection open longer. 1. 10 minutes 2. All the tables Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-query/connectors/azuresqldatabase

Only tables with data. If cleared, the navigator displays only the tables whose columns and rows contain data."
Hansen_G üëç 15 N/A
Navigate using full hierarchy is unchecked. Only table with data will be displayed.
CookieMingkee üëç 9 N/A

I cannot add a screenshot in this post but use the this link to use as a reference on how exactly the Navigator would look like using with the "Navigate using full hierarchy" is checked and unchecked. I connected to an Azure SQL Database with tables containing data and others are blank. Marking the "Navigate using full hierarchy" will list the Schemas first and the hierarchy for each object under each schema (e.g. dbo, db_onwer, etc.). Unmarking the "Navigate using full hierarchy" will show all the tables whether with data or without data.

If cleared, the navigator displays only the tables whose columns and rows contain data. Include relationship columns: If checked, includes columns that might have relationships to other tables. If this box is cleared, you won‚Äôt see those columns. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-query/connectors/azure-sql-database

Question 91
ID: 94599
You attempt to connect Power BI Desktop to a Cassandra database. From the Get Data connector list, you discover that there is no specific connector for the Cassandra database. You need to select an alternate data connector that will connect to the database. Which type of connector should you choose?

Options

  • A. Microsoft SQL Server database
  • B. ODBC
  • C. OLE DB
  • D. OData

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
GuerreiroJunior Selected: B üëç 53 N/A
B is Correct because, B¬¥cause it allows you to connect to data sources that aren't identified in the Get Data lists. The ODBC connector lets you import data from any third-party ODBC driver simply by specifying a Data Source Name (DSN) or a connection string. As an option, you can also specify a SQL statement to execute against the ODBC driver. List details a few examples of data sources to which Power BI Desktop can connect by using the generic ODBC interface: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/desktop-connect-using-generic-interfaces
Pinha üëç 36 N/A
The anwer is B * Cassandra has an ODBC driver available that can be used to connect to the database using the ODBC connector in Power BI. * Microsoft SQL Server database is specifically designed to connect to SQL Server databases, * OLE DB is designed to connect to Microsoft databases and other third-party databases, * OData is designed to connect to web-based data sources
MoxieTT üëç 10 N/A
Awful question. This is a prime example of why the current exam, is not fit for purpose and needs revamped. How is this relevant to the day-to-day role of a data analyst?
MoxieTT üëç 5 N/A
This was on the exam
sergeyitaly üëç 4 N/A
To connect Power BI Desktop to a Cassandra database when there is no specific connector available, you should choose option B: ODBC (Open Database Connectivity) connector. ODBC is a widely-used standard for connecting to various types of databases, including Cassandra. It provides a common interface that allows applications like Power BI to communicate with different database systems using the same API. By leveraging the ODBC connector, you can establish a connection to the Cassandra database and retrieve data for analysis and visualization in Power BI.
Igetmyrole üëç 4 N/A
B is the correct answer. ODBC (Open Database Connectivity) is a general-purpose data access that allows us to connect to a wide range of databases, including Cassandra, using ODBC drivers.
2pado Selected: B üëç 2 N/A

Question 92
ID: 94598
DRAG DROP - You publish a dataset that contains data from an on-premises Microsoft SQL Server database. The dataset must be refreshed daily. You need to ensure that the Power BI service can connect to the database and refresh the dataset. Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
svg10gh üëç 53 N/A
Current sequence looks good
SanaCanada üëç 36 N/A
Given Answer is correct Set up an on-premises data gateway: Download and install an on-premises data gateway on a machine that has access to the SQL Server database. Make sure that the gateway is registered to the same workspace as the dataset. Configure a data source: In the Power BI service, go to the dataset settings, and select the data source. Then, enter the necessary details, including the server name, database name, and credentials. Schedule refresh: In the dataset settings, go to the "Scheduled refresh" tab, and set up a refresh schedule. Ensure that the gateway is selected as the "Data source credentials" option. Publish the dataset: Finally, publish the dataset to the Power BI service. The dataset will be refreshed according to the schedule you set up, and the on-premises data gateway will allow the service to connect to the SQL Server database. No confusion, and no need to discuss further
LouStar2 üëç 12 N/A
Publish the dataset isn't one of the answers tho
Chenemi üëç 6 N/A
SETUP ON PREMISES DATA GATEWAY ADD DATA SOURCE ADD DATASET OWNER SCHEDULE REFRESH
panic_attack üëç 5 N/A
This was on the exam on 22/2/2024 (:
Heyzzzzzzzzzzzzzz üëç 4 N/A
Could anyone provide a link to this? Seem like this requires pragmatic experience
killershark üëç 4 N/A
One thing I didn't understand is that first we need to add data source and then configure an on-premises data gateway. Someone please help me understand why we are not following this order?
6f38739 üëç 4 N/A
This question is dumb AF, like it doesnt really matter if you create dataset or gateway first, all you need to remember is to have it ready before running refresh,
Igetmyrole üëç 4 N/A
Here are the correct Sequences: First Step : Add a data source. This involves specifying the connection details, such as the server's name, database name, and authentication credentials. Second Step: Configure an on-premises data gateway. The gateway acts as a bridge between our on-premises data sources and the Power BI service in the cloud. It allows secure data transfer and access. Third Step: Add the dataset owner to the data source. Ensure that the dataset owner (the Power BI user or service account) has appropriate permissions to access the on-premises SQL server database. This is important for successful data retrieval during refresh. Fourth Step: Configure a scheduled refresh. Schedule the refresh to occur daily to keep the dataset up to date.
lizbette üëç 3 N/A
3rd step should be add dataset owner to the data source
Question 93
ID: 86380
HOTSPOT - You need to create a measure that will return the percentage of late orders. How should you complete the DAX expression? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point. Hot Area:
Explanation:
Box 1: CALCULATE - CALCULATE evaluates an expression in a modified filter context. Syntax: CALCULATE(<expression>[, <filter1> [, <filter2> [, ◊í‚Ç¨¬¶]]]) expression - The expression to be evaluated. filter1, filter2,.. - (Optional) Boolean expressions or table expressions that defines filters, or filter modifier functions. Incorrect: * COUNTX - Counts the number of rows that contain a non-blank value or an expression that evaluates to a non-blank value, when evaluating an expression over a table. * CALCULATETABLE evaluates a table expression in a modified filter context. Syntax: CALCULATETABLE(<expression>[, <filter1> [, <filter2> [, ◊í‚Ç¨¬¶]]]) Expression - The table expression to be evaluated. Box 2: FILTER - FILTER returns a table that represents a subset of another table or expression. Syntax: FILTER(<table>,<filter>) Box 3: Orders[ShippedDate] > Orders[RequiredDate] Northwind Traders defines late orders as those shipped after the required shipping date. Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/calculate-function-dax https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/filter-function-dax
fred92 üëç 35 N/A
Answer is correct. CALCULATE FILTER Orders[ShippedDate] > Orders[RequiredDate]
Wadyba üëç 11 N/A
Correct Answer
lukelin08 üëç 7 N/A
Answer is correct. CALCULATE FILTER Orders[ShippedDate] > Orders[RequiredDate]
Shalaleh üëç 6 N/A
Given answer is correct.
Hoeishetmogelijk üëç 5 N/A
Answer is correct.
21ad543 üëç 1 N/A

Question 94
ID: 82709
What should you do to address the existing environment data concerns?

Options

  • A. a calculated column that uses the following formula: ABS(Sales[sales_amount])
  • B. a measure that uses the following formula: SUMX(FILTER('Sales', 'Sales'[sales_amount] > 0)),[sales_amount])
  • C. a measure that uses the following formula: SUM(Sales[sales_amount])
  • D. a calculated column that uses the following formula: IF(ISBLANK(Sales[sales_amount]),0, (Sales[sales_amount]))

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
fdsdfgxcvbdsfhshfg Selected: B üëç 30 N/A
legit answer ü§ôü§ôü§ô
lmrod Selected: B üëç 7 N/A
B is the only option that ignores blanks and negative values
Glubbs Selected: D üëç 4 N/A
B only if it had the correct parentheses as per this formula - tested. SUMX(FILTER('Sales', 'Sales'[sales_amount] > 0),[sales_amount])
amcken üëç 3 N/A
I think the extra parenthesis is just a typo. D would make blank sales value equal to 0 which would be included in the analysis which we don't want.
nmosq Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
The error in the formula for B it's probably just a typo. D option would work on the missing values, but not with the negative values
Jay_98_11 Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
Answer B has wrong syntax.
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
This measure ensures that only positive, non-blank sales_amount values contribute to the total. It directly addresses the data concern: ‚Äúnegative and missing sales_amount values do NOT contribute to the total sales amount calculation.‚Äù - FILTER('Sales', 'Sales'[sales_amount] > 0) excludes negative and blank values. - SUMX(...) iterates over the filtered table and sums the valid sales_amount values.
Astex56 üëç 2 N/A
B has 2 opening brackets '(', but 3 closing bracket ')'. A bit strange
Shalaleh Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
ABS return Absolute number. and we need a measure not a calculated column
AlejandroErazo üëç 1 N/A
The correct syntax should be: SUMX(FILTER('Sales', 'Sales'[sales_amount] > 0),Sales[sales_amount])
Question 95
ID: 82760
What should you create to meet the reporting requirements of the sales department?

Options

  • A. a measure that uses a formula of COUNTROWS(Sales)
  • B. a calculated column that use a formula of COUNTA(Sales[sales_id])
  • C. a calculated column that uses a formula of SUM(Sales[sales_id])
  • D. a measure that uses a formula of SUM(Sales[sales_id])

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
fred92 Selected: A üëç 10 N/A
Answer is correct
Hoeishetmogelijk Selected: A üëç 8 N/A
A is correct. It must be a count function and a measure.
Shalaleh üëç 3 N/A
we do not need calculated column! calculated column uses row- filter but we need a scaler value!
June15 üëç 3 N/A
B says it's a column, not a measure.
olajor üëç 2 N/A
Shouldn't it be B though? You don't want to count blank sales_ids
jaume Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
There is a requirement to not consider negative and missing sales_amount but this is just for the total sales_amount calculation so we should assume every row in the "sales" table stands for one single transaction and we should count all of them, so right answer should be option A counting the ROWS of he "Sales" table We need a measure to return a scalar and options B and C are about adding calculated columns. In option D it's suggested to SUM the [Sales_id] but there is no sense summing any field to count number of transactions and even less summing some Id which could be usin any coding to identify sales.
KAYBOL üëç 1 N/A
sales_ids are unique identifier (primary key) of the table; cant be null
21ad543 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
All we want is the Count. That narrows it down to A or B. We do not want a calculated column, just a measure. Answer is A.
Newb007 üëç 1 N/A

Question 96
ID: 156201
You have a Power BI tenant that contains a workspace named WS1. WS1 contains the following items: ‚Ä¢ A semantic model named SM1. ‚Ä¢ A report named RPT1 that is connected to SM1. ‚Ä¢ A report named RPT2 that is connected to SM1. ‚Ä¢ A report named RPT3 that is connected to SM1. ‚Ä¢ A dashboard named DB1 that contains content from RPT1 and RPT2. You need to grant workspace access to a group named Group1. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Group1 must be able to view RPT1, RPT2, and DB1. ‚Ä¢ Group1 must be prevented from viewing RPT3. ‚Ä¢ Group1 must be prevented from creating new reports and dashboards by using SM1. ‚Ä¢ Group1 must be prevented from sharing the reports and dashboards to other users. ‚Ä¢ Administrative effort must be minimized. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Publish an app.
  • B. Assign Group1 the Viewer role for WS1.
  • C. Store PBIX files in a shared folder in Microsoft OneDrive.
  • D. Share each item individually.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
MANANDAVEY Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
‚úÖ A. Publish an app. Explanation: Publishing an app in Power BI allows you to control which reports and dashboards are accessible to a specific audience while keeping administrative effort minimal. This approach meets all the given requirements: ‚úÖ Group1 can view RPT1, RPT2, and DB1 (you can include only these reports in the app). ‚úÖ Group1 is prevented from viewing RPT3 (since RPT3 will not be included in the app). ‚úÖ Group1 cannot create new reports or dashboards using SM1 (viewers of the app cannot modify the dataset). ‚úÖ Group1 cannot share reports and dashboards (app viewers cannot share content). ‚úÖ Minimal administrative effort (you only need to manage access to the app instead of configuring individual report permissions).
SylUK Selected: C üëç 3 N/A
C is the answer: Store PBIX files in a shared folder in Microsoft OneDrive. because the Group 1 will only view RPT1,RPT2 and DB1. A is wrong because it require an administrative effort. B is also wrong because viewer role will allow Group1 to read all reports in the workspace even RPT3 which is against the requirement. D also needs administrative effort. Therefore C is the correct answer in this context .
EdExamTopics Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Publishing an app allows you to selectively include RPT1, RPT2, and DB1 while excluding RPT3. This approach prevents Group1 from creating new reports and dashboards using SM1 and from sharing the content with other users. Additionally, it minimizes administrative effort by providing a centralized way to manage access.
SylUK üëç 2 N/A
Another explanation is: you can configure a shared folder in Microsoft One Drive to prevent users from creating new content or sharing it with other users, by adjusting the permission levels assigned to the folder; if you only give users "Read" access to a shared folder, they can only view existing files and cannot creates new ones or further share that content with others. So "Read" access can only view files within the folder, no create new ones or share them further, while "Edit" access can view, edit, and share files within the folder. So C Store PBIX files in a shared folder in Microsoft One Drive is the correct answer.
b2775a4 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
‚Ä¢ Group1 must view specific reports and dashboards (RPT1, RPT2, DB1): ‚Ä¢ Publishing an app allows you to share selected reports and dashboards with specific groups or users. ‚Ä¢ Group1 must be prevented from viewing RPT3: ‚Ä¢ Apps allow fine-grained control, so you can exclude RPT3 from the app content. ‚Ä¢ Group1 must not create new reports or dashboards or share content: ‚Ä¢ When users access content via an app, they cannot edit or create new reports/dashboards or share the app itself. ‚Ä¢ Minimize administrative effort: ‚Ä¢ Publishing an app is simpler and more manageable than other options.
21ad543 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
A. Publish an App. Didn't know that I could exclude RPT3 til reading the comments. I pick A.
Lulu_2022 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
- Selective visibility: When publishing an app, you can choose exactly which reports and dashboards to include‚Äîso you can publish RPT1, RPT2, and DB1, while excluding RPT3. - Read-only access: App users cannot create new content or build on the semantic model (SM1), which satisfies the requirement to prevent report/dashboard creation. - No reshare rights: App viewers cannot share the content with others unless explicitly allowed. - Low admin overhead: You manage access and permissions centrally through the app, which is far more efficient than managing individual report shares.
c3bd69b Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
C is Correct
Dusica üëç 1 N/A
C is more admin effort than A
Question 97
ID: 156045
You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that contains sales data. You need to ensure that Model1 is refreshed on the first day of each month to include last month‚Äôs sales data. What should you configure?

Options

  • A. a scheduled refresh
  • B. an incremental refresh
  • C. a Microsoft Power Automate flow
  • D. an on-premises data gateway

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Saiqua123 Selected: C üëç 7 N/A
pls correct me if i'm wrong, shouldn't it be C as per "Power BI does not have a monthly refresh interval option. However, you can use Power Automate to create a custom refresh interval that occurs monthly" //https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/refresh-scheduled-refresh#scheduled-refresh
Bildey Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
- a scheduled refresh While incremental refresh can help optimize the refresh process by refreshing only the data that has changed, it does not set the schedule for when the refresh happens. It helps with large datasets by minimizing data reloads, but it doesn‚Äôt solve the requirement of scheduling the refresh for the first day of each month.
FazzieA Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
The answer is correct as you cannot schedule refreshes to be once a month, the refresh frequency can be either daily or weekly. Incremental refresh will refresh the dataset for the last month with new data, the old data will not change.
Lulu_2022 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Here‚Äôs why: - A scheduled refresh allows you to configure specific days and times when Power BI should refresh your semantic model. - Since your goal is to refresh Model1 on the first day of each month, this aligns perfectly with the capabilities of scheduled refresh. - You can set this up in the Power BI Service under the dataset‚Äôs Settings > Scheduled refresh section. üîç Why not ? - B. Incremental refresh: Useful for optimizing performance when dealing with large datasets by refreshing only recent partitions‚Äîbut it doesn‚Äôt control when the refresh happens. You‚Äôd still need a scheduled refresh to trigger it.
b92fc92 Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
C in my opinion
SylUK Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
A is the answer : a scheduled refresh. In Power BI, "schedule refresh" means setting a recurring time to automatically refresh all data in a dataset, while "incremental refresh" only updates the new or changed data since the last refresh, allowing for faster updates on large datasets by avoiding unnecessary reloads of the entire data set. ( found on Google)
21ad543 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Answer is A. This exam has nothing to do with Power Automate? The answer should be A.
0002110 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Scheduled Refresh: Purpose: Scheduled refresh is used to automate the process of refreshing the dataset on a regular basis, e.g., daily, weekly, monthly. Use Case: You can schedule the refresh to happen automatically on a specific date or time. In your case, you want to refresh the dataset on the first day of each month. This could be done using scheduled refresh
LuisViotti Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Option A, checked with Chatgpt and Gemini.(both selected A with similar explanation)
Question 98
ID: 147021
You create a report by using Microsoft Power BI Desktop. The report uses data from a Microsoft SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS) tabular model located on your company's internal network. You plan to publish the report to the Power BI Service. What should you implement to ensure that users who consume the report from the Power BI Service have the most up-to-date data from the tabular model?

Options

  • A. a scheduled refresh of the semantic model
  • B. an OData feed
  • C. an On-premises data gateway
  • D. a subscription

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
rcaliandro Selected: C üëç 8 N/A
Similar to a previous question. C is the correct answer
jaume Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
This is the same as Question 22 also in topic 4, glad to see it's the same proposed solution
desibaby09 Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
C final and ONLY answer
21ad543 Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
Chose C based off it ENSURING that we could see the up to date data. This is assuming the data is DQ or has a refresh schedule if it's import. C.
Lulu_2022 Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
SSAS Tabular + Power BI = Live Connection (not Import or standard DirectQuery) - When you connect to an SSAS tabular model from Power BI Desktop, you‚Äôre using a Live connection by default. - A Live connection is technically a special type of DirectQuery, where all queries are executed against the SSAS model in real time‚Äîno data is imported into Power BI Desktop or the Power BI Service. - This type of connection requires an On-premises data gateway when published, because Power BI Service needs to ‚Äúreach into‚Äù your internal network to fetch data dynamically.
Question 99
ID: 94742
HOTSPOT - You have two Power BI workspaces named WorkspaceA and WorkspaceB. WorkspaceA contains two datasets named Sales and HR. You need to provide a user named User1 with access to the WorkspaceB. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Create reports that use the HR dataset. ‚Ä¢ Publish the reports to WorkspaceB. ‚Ä¢ Prevent the ability to modify the HR dataset. ‚Ä¢ Prevent the ability to add users to Workspaces. What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
mambamota üëç 33 N/A
Answer is ok
csillag üëç 10 N/A
the answer is correct
28485e1 üëç 8 N/A
This was on my exam 2/2024.
Shalaleh üëç 7 N/A
Answer is correct. To copy a report to another workspace, and to create a report in another workspace based on a dataset in the current workspace, you need Build permission for the dataset. You also need at least the Contributor role on the source and destination workspaces. For datasets in the original workspace, if you have at least the Contributor role, you automatically have Build permission through your workspace role.
reyn007 üëç 4 N/A
The answer given is correct. Build and contributor role to workspace B because the user already has build permission for the HR dataset in workspace A and now should be able to publish in workspace B, so the user should be given Contributor role to workspace B.
lmrod üëç 4 N/A
In my opinion, correct...
Shalaleh üëç 4 N/A
Build permission applies to datasets. When you give users Build permission, they can build new content on your dataset, such as reports, dashboards, pinned tiles from Q&A, paginated reports, and Insights discovery. If a report outside the dataset workspace uses your dataset, you can't delete the dataset. If you try to do so, you get an error message. from Microsoft site
glenman0202 üëç 3 N/A
No, because you don't need to be a Contributor to use a dataset, you only need build permission, which does not require a role. Also, the principle of least privilege says that you shouldn't give a user more access than they need, and the Contributor roll is far more access than is needed for the requirements of the question. Given that other questions in this exam have explicitly mentioned the principle of least privilege, I'd wager that "Assign User1 the Contributor role for WorkspaceA" is an invalid answer.
Shalaleh üëç 2 N/A
for sure first part is giving Built Permission.
Neilsy üëç 2 N/A
need to be users in both workspaces hence contributor option for both is only valid option available. contributor automatically gives you build permission. You can't be granted build permission unless you have access to the workspace eg at least viewer access.

ID: 84560

fred92 üëç 73 N/A

When you share a report or dashboard built on that dataset, you can specify that the recipients also get Build permission for the underlying dataset."
Hongzu13 üëç 14 N/A
I took this from Ms documentation: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/service-datasets-build-permissions "Ways to give Build permission": (...) Say you have Reshare and Build permission on a dataset. When you share a report or dashboard built on that dataset, you can specify that the recipients also get Build permission for the underlying dataset. So the answer is: - Analyze in Excel - Grant build permission
Wadyba üëç 6 N/A
Users with read permission can not grant Build access, so the answer is Read permission.
Hoeishetmogelijk üëç 4 N/A

AzSheh üëç 4 N/A
- Analyze in Excel - Grant build permission If you have Reshare and Build permission on a dataset, and you share a report or dashboard you built on that dataset, you can specify that the recipients also get Build permission for the dataset. For more information, see Share Power BI reports and dashboards with coworkers and others. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/service-datasets-build-permissions
9f73003 üëç 3 N/A
- Analyze in Excel - Grant Build permission If you have Reshare and Build permission on a semantic model, and you share a report or dashboard you built on that semantic model, you can specify that the recipients also get Build permission for the semantic model. For more information, see Share Power BI reports and dashboards with coworkers and others.

B, B "Reshare" capability includes the ability to grant others access to view the dataset. They cannot grant the "Build" permission unless they have administrative rights or ownership of the dataset. So the completed statement would be: Users in the corp group can grant the Read permission for the dataset.
Flix üëç 2 N/A
f you have Reshare and Build permission on a semantic model, and you share a report or dashboard you built on that semantic model, you can specify that the recipients also get Build permission for the semantic model.
