Question 143
ID: 104364
You plan to use Power BI to create sales invoices for customers. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Sales invoices must be exported in a PDF format. ‚Ä¢ The PDF exports must show all columns and rows clearly. What should you create?

Options

  • A. a paginated report that contains a tablix
  • B. a dashboard that contains a table
  • C. an interactive report that contains a table
  • D. an interactive report that contains a matrix

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
XiangIvyLi Selected: A üëç 18 N/A
This is a tutorial video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Fcf8eXRq2E
SamuComqi Selected: A üëç 15 N/A
I passed the exam today (948/1000). My answer was: - a paginated report that contains a tablix
ushakiranr Selected: A üëç 5 N/A
a paginated report that contains a tablix
Pas77789 üëç 3 N/A
A paginated report that contains a tablix
omath Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A. a paginated report that contains a tablix. - Paginated reports are designed for pixel-perfect, printable layouts such as invoices, financial statements, or forms. - They use the tablix control (a flexible table/matrix) to display all rows and columns without truncation or scroll bars. - When exported to PDF, the entire dataset is rendered across multiple pages if necessary, ensuring nothing is cut off. - This is the standard approach for invoices because they require a fixed, professional layout suitable for customers.
Dsbuff Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A. a paginated report that contains a tablix.
AdrianBalescu üëç 1 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/reporting-services/report-design/tablix-data-region-report-builder-and-ssrs?view=sql-server-ver16
rcaliandro Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
I agree with A, but is "tablix" a typo? We mean table or matrix?
539d541 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Paginated report
jaume Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
Agree with the paginated report solution
Question 144
ID: 104362
DRAG DROP - You have a Power BI report that contains five bookmarks. You need to add an object to the report from which users can navigate between three specific bookmarks. How should you complete the task? To answer, drag the appropriate actions to the correct steps. Each action may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Turmalino üëç 82 N/A
Shouldn't it be the other way around: Second step: Group the three bookmarks Third step: Change the Bookmark property for the button. Otherwise the group is not available to be chosen in the property.
madyjoe21 üëç 12 N/A
Agree! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IdXK470YwAQ
JudT üëç 11 N/A
Tested: 1 - Add the bookmark Navogator button 2 - Group the three bookmarks 3 - Change the Bookmark property for the button
XiangIvyLi üëç 9 N/A
I agree with Turmalino, you have to group three bookmarks and then choose the group name you want to show in the Format Navigator, the video helps https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IdXK470YwAQ
UlyUkr üëç 5 N/A
Correct answer is: Second step: Group the three bookmarks Third step: Change the Bookmark property for the button.
ushakiranr üëç 2 N/A
The answer is correct!
e3ddceb üëç 1 N/A
The correct sequence is: Add a bookmark navigation button -> Group the three bookmarks -> Change the Bookmark property for the button.
Lulu_2022 üëç 1 N/A
Correct Order of Actions: Group the three bookmarks ‚Üí This step organizes the bookmarks you want to include in the navigator and allows you to isolate them from the others. Insert a bookmark navigator ‚Üí Go to Insert ‚Üí Buttons ‚Üí Navigator ‚Üí Bookmark navigator. This automatically creates a set of buttons linked to your bookmarks. Configure the navigator to use the bookmark group ‚Üí In the Format pane, under Bookmarks, select the group you created so only those three bookmarks appear in the navigator.
omath üëç 1 N/A
2. Group the three bookmarks. - In the Bookmarks pane, select the three bookmarks you want to include. - Right-click ‚Üí Group. - This creates a bookmark group that can be referenced by the navigator. 3. Change the Bookmark property for the button (to point to that group). - Select the Bookmark navigator button. - In the Format pane ‚Üí Navigator ‚Üí Bookmarks, set it to use the group you created. - Now, the navigator only cycles through those three bookmarks.
Dani_eL üëç 1 N/A
You will first group the bookmarks you want to pilot; Then Add A bookmark Navigator Finally Format > Bookmarks > select group
Question 145
ID: 154128
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have an on-premises data gateway. You need to reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models that run in Import storage mode. Solution: You decrease the dashboard cache update frequency. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
Dashboard cache update frequency controls how often Power BI refreshes the visual cache for dashboards ‚Äî it affects how frequently visuals are updated for users, not how much data is sent through the on-premises data gateway. In Import mode, data is only sent through the gateway during scheduled or manual refreshes. The dashboard cache setting doesn‚Äôt influence the volume of data transferred during those refreshes. ‚úÖ What would help instead: Filter or reduce rows/columns in Power Query before loading. Use aggregations to summarize data before import. Implement incremental refresh to avoid reloading historical data.
fehler Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
Decreasing the dashboard cache update frequency might not directly reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models in Import storage mode.
SylUK Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
The answer is A-YES because: To reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models in Import storage mode, decreasing the dashboard cache update frequency is a valid solution because it means the gateway will need to fetch updated data from the source less often, minimizing the data transfer volume.
0e11c58 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Chat GPT: The dashboard cache update frequency determines how often Power BI refreshes the dashboard visuals from the dataset. Adjusting this frequency does not directly reduce the amount of data sent through the on-premises data gateway for semantic models in Import storage mode.
13a8051 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
‚ùå No Reason: Decreasing the dashboard cache update frequency only affects how often dashboards pull updated data from the dataset already in Power BI service. It does not change how much data is imported from the on-premises source through the gateway in Import mode. To reduce gateway traffic, you‚Äôd need solutions like incremental refresh or aggregations.
f83734b üëç 1 N/A
Reducing the update frequency is a direct method to reduce data transfer through the gateway.
Question 146
ID: 148593
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have an on-premises data gateway. You need to reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models that run in import storage mode. Solution: You configure incremental refresh. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
jaume Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Incremental refresh would only refresh the "variable" part of the data (set using parameters) and would reduce the traffic not all the entire dataset would be refreshed
ec338ed Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Incremental refresh allows you to load only new or changed data, rather than refreshing the entire dataset. This can significantly reduce the amount of data that needs to be processed and transferred, especially in large datasets.
f07fa5c Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
Incremental reloads do reduce the workload
Rob_vd_Brink üëç 3 N/A
I think using incremental reloads DOES reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway, so option A
LuluSkyy üëç 2 N/A
The correct answer should be A. Incremental refresh refreshes the latest data
f07fa5c üëç 1 N/A

amiruladliroslibin Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
should be A
13a8051 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
‚úÖ Yes Reason: In Import mode, configuring incremental refresh means only new or changed data is loaded through the on-premises data gateway instead of reloading the entire dataset each time. This directly reduces the volume of data sent through the gateway.
Question 147
ID: 148848
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have an on-premises data gateway. You need to reduce the amount of data sent through the gateway by semantic models that run in import storage mode. Solution: You increase Automatic page refresh intervals. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
VladStan Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
1) Nothing to do with On-Prem data gateway 2) It can be used with DirectQuery storage mode only https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-automatic-page-refresh
LuluSkyy üëç 2 N/A
The correct answer is No. Automatic Refresh can only be used in direct query mode
jaume Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
First reason is Automatic Refresh is not available for Import mode as in our scenario but using DirectQuery mode. Even when we would be in a DirectQuery scenario, increasing the refresh would cause an increase on the traffic so the opposite effect
SylUK Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
The given answer is correct (B): because if you increase Automatic page refresh intervals., it would also increase the amount of data sent through the gateway and therefore goes against the requirement.
Pey1nkh Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
creating aggregations reduces the amount of data sent through the gateway and optimizes data refresh and query performance.
13a8051 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Answer: ‚ùå No Reason: In Import mode, reports load data from the imported cache in Power BI, not directly from the source. Changing automatic page refresh intervals affects DirectQuery or live connections, but it doesn‚Äôt reduce the data sent through the gateway during scheduled refreshes. It won't minimize gateway data transfer for Import mode.
sroumi Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
No, increasing Automatic page refresh intervals does not meet the goal of reducing the amount of data sent through the on-premises data gateway by semantic models running in Import storage mode. Here's why: Automatic Page Refresh (Report Level): Automatic page refresh controls how frequently the visuals on a report page are updated. It instructs the Power BI service to periodically query the existing, already imported data in the semantic model to refresh the visuals. It doesn't affect the amount of data transferred into the semantic model during a scheduled or manual data refresh.
Question 148
ID: 147010
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You have a Power BI report that imports a date table and a sales table from an Azure SQL database data source. The sales table has the following date foreign keys: ‚Ä¢ Due Date ‚Ä¢ Order Date ‚Ä¢ Delivery Date You need to support the analysis of sales over time based on all the date foreign keys. Solution: From the Fields pane, you rename the date table as Due Date. You use a DAX expression to create Order Date and Delivery Date as calculated tables. You create active relationships between the sales table and each date table. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
7eb1fdb üëç 5 N/A
Deja vu
Endeetheanalyst üëç 3 N/A
No is the correct answer
jaume Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Same question as Q77 but also same answer :-)
amiruladliroslibin Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
In Power BI, only one active relationship can exist between two tables at a time. By renaming the date table as "Due Date" and creating calculated tables for "Order Date" and "Delivery Date", you are essentially creating multiple date tables and attempting to establish multiple active relationships with the sales table.
Jayaruwan Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Yes is the correct answer
nelrosell üëç 2 N/A
Yes - correct
rcaliandro Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Yes, is the correct answer
Tex02 üëç 2 N/A
I would have thought the Answer is yes as you create the other required tables using the dax function and create relationships to the required dates
Monsta Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Yes is the correct answer
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Power BI allows only one active relationship between a fact table (like Sales) and a given dimension table (like Date). Creating calculated tables using DAX for Order Date and Delivery Date based on the original Date table does not create independent role-playing dimensions ‚Äî they are still tied to the same underlying data and metadata. Attempting to create active relationships from all three date columns in the Sales table to these calculated tables will likely result in ambiguity or errors, and it increases model complexity unnecessarily.
Question 149
ID: 134813
You are reviewing a Power BI data model. You have a calculated table that has the following definition. ProductList = INTERSECT ( ProductsGroupA, ProductsGroupB ) You need to identify the results of the DAX expression. Which rows will be returned in ProductList?

Options

  • A. all the rows in ProductsGroupB that have a matching row in ProductsGroupA
  • B. all the rows in both tables
  • C. all the rows in ProductsGroupA that have a matching row in ProductsGroupB
  • D. all the rows in ProductsGroupA that have no matching row in ProductsGroupB.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
INDEAVR Selected: C üëç 13 N/A
C. all the rows in ProductsGroupA that have a matching row in ProductsGroupB
iamamantrivedi üëç 4 N/A
The INTERSECT function in DAX is order-independent. It returns the common rows between two tables, regardless of the order in which you specify the tables. both a and c are correct.
Stehi üëç 3 N/A
Would not A and C be both correct? ince INTERSECT finds rows that exist in both tables, the statement is correct from the perspective of either table‚Äîwhether you're looking for matches in ProductsGroupA against ProductsGroupB or vice versa. The result is a table with rows that are common to both.
rajukg üëç 2 N/A
Intersect is not commutative. In general, Intersect(T1, T2) will have a different result set than Intersect(T2, T1). Duplicate rows are retained. If a row appears in table_expression1 and table_expression2, it and all duplicates in table_expression_1 are included in the result set.
rajukg üëç 2 N/A
Answer: C
jaume Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
INTERSECT return the row-wise intersection of two tables. This means it retrieves only the rows that are present in both table expressions
shahrzadkhb Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
The answer is correct. INTERSECT(<table_expression1>, <table_expression2>) Duplicate rows are retained. If a row appears in table_expression1 and table_expression2, it and any duplicates in table_expression_1 are included in the result set. Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/sv-se/dax/intersect-function-dax
13a8051 Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
C. all the rows in ProductsGroupA that have a matching row in ProductsGroupB Explanation: The INTERSECT function returns the rows that appear in both tables. The result contains only the rows from the first table (ProductsGroupA) that also exist in the second table (ProductsGroupB). It does not return rows from both tables combined, only the matching ones from the first table.
rcaliandro Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
C - all the rows in ProductsGroupA that have a matching row in ProductsGroupB
Florinuca üëç 1 N/A
The correct answer is C. See the example : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/intersect-function-dax "Intersect is not commutative. In general, Intersect(T1, T2) will have a different result set than Intersect(T2, T1)."

  • B. one-to-one between Customer and Transaction
  • C. many-to-many between Customer and Transaction
  • D. one-to-many from Customer to Transaction

Question 151
ID: 81960
You have a custom connector that returns ID, From, To, Subject, Body, and Has Attachments for every email sent during the past year. More than 10 million records are returned. You build a report analyzing the internal networks of employees based on whom they send emails to. You need to prevent report recipients from reading the analyzed emails. The solution must minimize the model size. What should you do?

Options

  • A. From Model view, set the Subject and Body columns to Hidden.
  • B. Remove the Subject and Body columns during the import.
  • C. Implement row-level security (RLS) so that the report recipients can only see results based on the emails they sent.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
RazaTheLegend Selected: B üëç 46 N/A
B is the best option to prevent report recipients from reading the analyzed emails and minimize the model size. Removing the Subject and Body columns during the import process ensures that they are not included in the model, which prevents report recipients from being able to access the analyzed email content. A and C are not effective solutions for preventing report recipients from reading the analyzed emails. A: Hiding the Subject and Body columns in the model view may prevent report recipients from seeing the content in the report, but the data is still stored in the model and can potentially be accessed by someone with the appropriate permissions. C: Implementing row-level security (RLS) restricts data access based on user roles or permissions, but it does not prevent access to the analyzed email content in the model. No confusion, and no need to discuss further
RickyAnd Selected: B üëç 17 N/A
correct, "prevent report recipients from reading the analyzed emails"
Tareqk üëç 4 N/A
This is was on the exam today. 2024-04-19
inejo üëç 4 N/A
Gracias por tu explicaci√≥n :)
louisaok üëç 3 N/A
Remove the sensitive info at the very beginning
SanaCanada Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
B is the best option to prevent report recipients from reading the analyzed emails and minimize the model size. Removing the Subject and Body columns during the import process ensures that they are not included in the model, which prevents report recipients from being able to access the analyzed email content. A and C are not effective solutions for preventing report recipients from reading the analyzed emails. A: Hiding the Subject and Body columns in the model view may prevent report recipients from seeing the content in the report, but the data is still stored in the model and can potentially be accessed by someone with the appropriate permissions. C: Implementing row-level security (RLS) restricts data access based on user roles or permissions, but it does not prevent access to the analyzed email content in the model. No confusion, and no need to discuss further
Igetmyrole üëç 2 N/A
C is the correct answer. In this scenario, we want to prevent report recipients from reading the analyzed emails while still allowing them to analyze internal networks based on whom employees send emails to. To achieve this this goal while minimizing the model size, implementing row-level security (RLS) is the most appropriate solution. Option A doesn't prevent access to the underlying data. Option B might limit our ability to perform analysis based on the content of emails.
kenyJen üëç 2 N/A
But it doesn't minimize the model size.
benni_ale Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
CLS is not available in Power Bi so we either Mask or remove the columns. Mask them though still potentially leaves chances to view the data.
Dani_eL Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
dissect the question and only keep key elements: custom connector : ID, From, To, Subject, Body, and Has Attachments -build a report analyzing send emails to. -prevent report from reading emails. -minimize the model size. What should you do? Pretty obvious you only need to keep : [ID, From, To], right ?
Question 152
ID: 80325
You have a Power BI query named Sales that imports the columns shown in the following table. Users only use the date part of the Sales_Date field. Only rows with a Status of Finished are used in analysis. You need to reduce the load times of the query without affecting the analysis. Which two actions achieve this goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Options

  • A. Remove the rows in which Sales[Status] has a value of Canceled.
  • B. Remove Sales[Sales_Date].
  • C. Change the data type of Sale[Delivery_Time] to Integer.
  • D. Split Sales[Sale_Date] into separate date and time columns.
  • E. Remove Sales[Canceled Date].

Answer

Suggested Answer:
AE
bjornopjemic üëç 130 N/A
A, only records with state finished are used D, personally I would transform the column to a date format and not split it since only the date part is used Not E, All the cancelled rows are already deleted with A and when a order is not cancelled it will contain a null value
evipap Selected: AE üëç 66 N/A
It says: You need to reduce the LOAD times of the query without affecting the analysis. Only answers A and E can reduce the load times. D may reduce only the time needed to process the data. Someone said that E is not the answer because: "All the cancelled rows are already deleted with A and when a order is not cancelled it will contain a null value". You must read again the decription cause it says " Each answer presents a COMPLETE solutiuon" not part of a solution.
nevesrf üëç 7 N/A
"Each correct answer presents a complete solution." so your choice to choose A have nothing to do with the choice to choose E they are independent answers to me the most effective is A and E, think if you only have tho pick E or D the better choice is E for shure
1CY1 üëç 6 N/A
Each answer represents a complete solution. -> D cannot be correct as it is not a complete solution. -> A, E : Correct.
Maniula üëç 6 N/A
You focus too much on load. Answer E doesn't resolve the date part of the question. Splitting columns is correct, not E.
semauni üëç 5 N/A
"Separate date and time, if bound together. If any of your tables have columns that combine date and time, make sure that you separate them into distinct columns before importing them into Power BI. This approach will increase compression abilities." Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/get-data/8-performance-issues
taod üëç 5 N/A
I was on the Track of AD, but I think you are right. Splitting up [Sale_Date] alone doesn't help us with faster load times (the question is not about performance). Also, analyzing the two options separately ("Each correct answer presents a complete solution"), deleting [Canceled_Date] for sure is a right answer.
reignreign03 üëç 5 N/A
I agree here as well. Choosing D (splitting up [Sales_Date]) may even increase the LOAD time of the query, even though it might decrease its PROCESSING time. E (removing [Canceled_Date]) on the other hand removes an entire column to be loaded, thereby decreasing the LOAD time.
Vaar üëç 2 N/A
When deleting all rows with status equal to cancelled, all remaining rows will have null value in the column "cancel date". Would it not therefore be a very good idea to delete this row, not leaving it taking up completely unnecessary space?
MANANDAVEY Selected: AD üëç 2 N/A
Redueses the load and nowhere it mentioned to remove the column.

  • B. Admin
  • C. Contributor
  • D. Member

D

Question 154
ID: 86032
You have a Power BI report. You have a table named Data1 that contains 10 million rows. Data1 is used in the following visuals: ‚úë A card that shows the number of records ‚úë A bar chart that shows total transaction amount by territory ‚úë A scatter plot that shows transaction amount and profit amount on the axes and points colored by territory You need to modify the scatter plot to make it easier for users to identify meaningful patterns. The solution must not affect the accuracy of the other visuals. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Add a count field of the transaction amount to the size bucket of the scatter plot.
  • B. Add a trend line to the scatter plot.
  • C. Enable high-density sampling on the scatter plot.
  • D. Apply a row filter to the Data1 query in Power Query Editor.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
shakes103 Selected: C üëç 49 N/A
This question requires "modification" of the scatter plot and what high-density sampling essentially does is to employ methods that capture and represent the underlying data more effectively and eliminates overlapping points. Remember that the table named Data1 contains 10 million rows. How do you represent all that data in a scatter plot in a meaningful pattern for easy understanding and analysis? by use of high density sampling. "By definition, high-density data is sampled to create visualizations reasonably quickly that are responsive to interactivity. Too many data points on a visual can bog it down, and can detract from the visibility of trends". This link explains it more: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-high-density-scatter-charts#how-high-density-scatter-charts-work
Clodia Selected: C üëç 11 N/A
The correct answer should be C - Enable high-density sampling on the scatter plot. Trend line is only available if the X axis is time and type is "Continuous", in this case the option is not available.
LanTodak üëç 7 N/A
Exam: 15/10/2023 Score: 948/1000 Answer: C
Fer079 üëç 6 N/A
You are wrong. Trend line is available even if the X axis is not time. You can see this example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mMTAIHBtB80 So Trend line is the best option
Diogo1998 üëç 6 N/A
You're a bot
temor Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
The best option for modifying the scatter plot in Power BI to make it easier for users to identify meaningful patterns, without affecting the accuracy of the other visuals, is: B. Add a trend line to the scatter plot. Adding a trend line to the scatter plot in Power BI would enhance the visualization's ability to reveal patterns or trends in the data. This approach is beneficial because it doesn't impact the underlying data used in other visuals, such as the card showing the number of records or the bar chart displaying total transaction amounts by territory. Trend lines provide a visual representation of the general direction of the data, making it easier to identify relationships and patterns without altering the data itself. This approach seems to be the most suitable and voted for, considering the requirements of maintaining the accuracy of other visuals and aiding in the identification of meaningful patterns in the scatter plot.
Dsbuff Selected: C üëç 3 N/A
The keyword in the question is: "10 million rows" => C. Enable high-density sampling on the scatter plot.
thomas_90 üëç 3 N/A
For my opinion, B is correct answer. Because the scatter plot that made by grouping territories, so it doesn't have too much points. In this case, the trend line will be more effective for users to understand the pattern of data.
panic_attack üëç 2 N/A
This was on the exam on 22/2/2024 (:
NaudeDucon Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Don't just rely too much on the wording of documentation, let's consider the question on Statistical sense. The question focus on the EASE of detecting PATTERN, so B - adding a trend line make sense. A trend line visibly show the (linear) relationship between 2 variables: upward - positive, downward - negative, so it help users see the pattern on the spot. And ofc, it's not just for time series data like some other comments has mentioned. Increase higher density of data (C) is basically increase the representation degree of the sample compared to the population. Of course the better representative the sample, the more accurate the trend on the chart. But the point is: this option increase the ACCURACY, not the EASE OF DETECTING PATTERN. Even if the data on scatter chart is more accurately representive, but a bunch of points on it is not easier to show pattern than a trend line, right?
Question 155
ID: 146912
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI tenant that contains a workspace. The workspace contains a dataset named datasetA. You need to build a pivot table report in Microsoft Excel. The report must use datasetA as the data source. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Ensure that the report can be refreshed to get the latest available data from the Power BI service. ‚Ä¢ Ensure that all the visible data in datasetA is available for use in Excel. What should you do to connect Excel to datasetA, and which element in datasetA will be incompatible with the Excel connection? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Jayaruwan üëç 6 N/A
Given answers are correct
hatem.ayed üëç 5 N/A
Para conectar Excel a datasetA: Select Analyze in Excel: Esta opci√≥n te permite conectar Excel directamente a un conjunto de datos en Power BI usando "Analizar en Excel". Esto es lo que necesitas para crear un informe de tabla din√°mica en Excel que se puede actualizar con los datos m√°s recientes desde el servicio Power BI. Incompatible con la conexi√≥n a Excel: Field parameters: Los par√°metros de campo (Field parameters) en Power BI no son totalmente compatibles con las conexiones a Excel. Esto puede causar problemas al intentar utilizar estas caracter√≠sticas avanzadas en un entorno de Excel. Por lo tanto, las selecciones correctas son: Para conectar Excel a datasetA: Select Analyze in Excel. Incompatible con la conexi√≥n a Excel: Field parameters.
Tex02 üëç 4 N/A
I had a dataset in powerbi.com and was able to open it with the Analyze in Excel so I say these answer are correct
ec338ed üëç 2 N/A
Report Measures is the correct answer: Report measures in Power BI are often incompatible with Excel connections when using a live connection because they are tightly integrated with specific visualizations and context in Power BI. While basic measures will work, report-level measures, especially those related to specific visual filters or slicers in Power BI reports, may not transfer correctly into Excel.
tko86 üëç 2 N/A
Field Parameters are incompatible in Excel from powerbi datasets. Those field parameters allow users to dynamically change the field/data. You cannot use PBI dataset parameters in Anlayze in Excel. You can use the implicit and explicit measures that were created in PowerBi dataset.
Odidepse üëç 2 N/A
Analyze in excel allows you to have direct connection to dataset field parameters is incompatibleields based on field parameters in the dataset will not be accessible when using Excel
esrath üëç 1 N/A
Use a live connection & Report Measures. According to the documentation here: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/collaborate-share/service-analyze-in-excel#export-to-excel-with-live-connection Excerpts: "- Export to Excel with live connection While viewing a Power BI visual, you may want to further explore the visual data in Excel and keep the data connected. You can export a table of refreshable data from a Power BI visual to Excel." & "If you use the Export with live connection option to export data from a visual in that report, the measures that you added won't be available in the data you export to Excel."
Question 156
ID: 83087
DRAG DROP - You need create a date table in Power BI that must contain 10 full calendar years, including the current year. How should you complete the DAX expression? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point. Select and Place:
Explanation:
Box 1: YEAR - Get the current year. Box 2: TODAY - TODAY returns the current date. Box 3: CALENDAR - CALENDAR returns a table with a single column named ◊í‚Ç¨Date◊í‚Ç¨ containing a contiguous set of dates. The range of dates is from the specified start date to the specified end date, inclusive of those two dates. The following formula returns a table with dates between January 1st, 2005 and December 31st, 2015. CALENDAR ( DATE ( 2005, 1, 1 ), DATE ( 2015, 12, 31 ) Reference: https://dax.guide/calendar/
Namenick10 üëç 70 N/A
Year Today Calendar
mahtab üëç 13 N/A
Correct : Year Today Calendar
Igetmyrole üëç 9 N/A
Year Today Calendar Year: calculates the starting year for the date table. Today: simply assigns the current date. Calendar: is used to generate a date table. It starts from January 1st of the year and goes up to December 31st of the current year.
lukelin08 üëç 5 N/A
Answer is correct
Helena1 üëç 5 N/A
Yes, it does. This range included in the explanation is actually 11 years: DATE ( 2005, 1, 1 ), DATE ( 2015, 12, 31 ). So, subtracting 9 gives you 10 full years counting from the first full year till the end year.
discoverp üëç 4 N/A
There is no typo here. The DATE(var1 -9, 01,01) is meant to subtract 9 from the value of var1 which in turn is a YEAR value of TODAY()'s date.
vat4444 üëç 4 N/A
Answer given is correct Date = var var1 = YEAR(TODAY()) return CALENDAR(DATE(var1 - 9,01,01), DATE(var1,12,31) )
samad1234 üëç 4 N/A
The answer is correct
rcaliandro üëç 3 N/A
The answer is correct, YEAR - TODAY - CALENDAR is the correct sequence

Question 157
ID: 79836
You import a Power BI dataset that contains the following tables: ‚úë Date ‚úë Product ‚úë Product Inventory The Product Inventory table contains 25 million rows. A sample of the data is shown in the following table. The Product Inventory table relates to the Date table by using the DateKey column. The Product Inventory table relates to the Product table by using the ProductKey column. You need to reduce the size of the data model without losing information. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Change Summarization for DateKey to Don't Summarize.
  • B. Remove the relationship between Date and Product Inventory
  • C. Change the data type of UnitCost to Integer.
  • D. Remove MovementDate.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D

Removing relationship would make impossible to set any analysis based on date (you could split DateKey column and get from there day, month and year but this would increase data model size) Changing UnitCost to Integer (this category doesn't exist in PBI but Whole Number!!!) would result in lost of information as values in this column are all decimals

Question 158
ID: 148490
You publish a semantic model to the Power BI service. The semantic model contains data from the following data sources: ‚Ä¢ Source1: A Microsoft Excel file stored in Microsoft OneDrive for Business ‚Ä¢ Source2: An Azure SQL database on a virtual network ‚Ä¢ Source3: A public website Which data sources require an on-premises data gateway?

Options

  • A. Source1 only
  • B. Source2 only
  • C. Source3 only
  • D. Source1 and Source2 only
  • E. Source2 and Source3 only
  • F. Source1, Source2, and Source3

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
VladStan Selected: B üëç 9 N/A
You need a gateway to connect to data sources that are located in a private network, such as an Azure Virtual Network (Azure VNet). A virtual network, or VNet, is a logically isolated segment of a network that insulates traffic from the public internet. A VNet provides enhanced network security. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/guidance/powerbi-implementation-planning-data-gateways Excel file you can access via SharePoint connector and a public site is well... a public site...
jaume Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
Virtual network is the only requiring a GW as the rest should be available to all users (Organization users I mean, OneDrive for Business should be available for the company users owning such OneDrive)
tko86 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
An Azure SQL database inside a virtual network is not publicly accessible by default. It's protected by the VNet's network security rules. Therefore, you must use a data gateway to allow Power BI to connect to it. The gateway acts as a bridge between the Power BI service and the VNet. Remember, an on-premises data gateway is required when Power BI needs to access data sources that are not directly accessible over the internet.
LuluSkyy üëç 2 N/A
The correct answer is B. Reason is because Power Bi cannot access the virtual network without a gateway path. The excel file can be easily accessed by powerBi likewise the public website.
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Source1 (Excel in OneDrive for Business): Does not require a gateway. Power BI can connect directly to cloud-based files like Excel in OneDrive or SharePoint Online. Source2 (Azure SQL database on a virtual network): Does require a gateway if the database is not accessible over the public internet ‚Äî which is typically the case when it's secured inside a virtual network. Source3 (Public website): Does not require a gateway. Power BI can access public web data sources directly without a gateway. So only Source2 needs an on-premises data gateway to bridge the secure virtual network and the Power BI service
omath Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: B. Source2 only * Explanation: - Even though it‚Äôs an Azure service, if the database is secured inside a virtual network (VNet) or behind a firewall, Power BI Service cannot access it directly. - You need either an on-premises data gateway or a virtual network data gateway to bridge the connection. * Why not the others: - Source1: Excel in OneDrive for Business Files stored in OneDrive for Business or SharePoint Online are already in the Microsoft cloud. Power BI can connect and refresh them directly without a gateway. - Source3: Public website Publicly accessible data sources (like web scraping or APIs without authentication/firewall restrictions) can be accessed directly by Power BI Service. No gateway is required.
Question 159
ID: 147096
You have a Power BI model that contains two tables named Sales and Date. The Sales table relates to the Date table by using a many-to-one relationship. The Sales table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Date ‚Ä¢ Product ‚Ä¢ SalesAmount You need to create a DAX measure for a rolling 31-day sales total that will return the total sales amount for a selected date and the previous 30 days. Which DAX expression should you use?

Options

  • A. CALCULATE(SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), DATEADD(Date[Date], -30, DAY))
  • B. CALCULATE(SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), DATESBETWEEN(Date[Date], Max('Date'[Date])-30, Max('Date'[Date])))
  • C. CALCULATE(SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), DATESMTD(Date[Date]))
  • D. CALCULATE(SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), DISTINCTCOUNT(Date[Date]) = 31)

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
MonikaStop Selected: B üëç 14 N/A
DATESBETWEEN creates a continuous range of dates from the selected date back 30 days. So option B is more suitable for calculating a rolling 31-day total because it correctly defines the date range needed for the calculation.
Jayaruwan Selected: A üëç 7 N/A
Answer A is correct because Dateadd provides required set of dates
shedi13 üëç 3 N/A
I would say A, but after testing im certain thats B
tko86 üëç 3 N/A
A. CALCULATE(SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), DATEADD(Date[Date], -30, DAY)): This is incorrect because DATEADD shifts the entire date context by 30 days. It doesn't create a range of dates. It would calculate the sales for the single day 30 days prior to the currently filtered date, not for the 31-day period.
Pey1nkh Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
The DATESBETWEEN function defines a range of dates: From MAX(Date[Date]) - 30 (30 days before the selected date) To MAX(Date[Date]) (the selected date). This correctly captures all dates in the 31-day rolling window. why not Dateadd: The DATEADD function shifts the entire date context backward by 30 days. This means the calculation will consider only the values on dates exactly 30 days ago and not the entire rolling range of 31 days.
jaume Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
DATEADD would return the selected date shifted back 30 days not a period. DATESBETWEEN will return the desired period for the calculation
3433bf6 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
B DATESBETWEEN as DATEADD returns only 1date while we need a series of dates.
omath Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
* Answer: B. * Explanation: - CALCULATE changes the filter context to a custom date range. - DATESBETWEEN defines a continuous window of dates. Here, it starts at the selected date minus 30 days and ends at the selected date. - This gives you exactly 31 days of sales (the current day + 30 previous days). * Why not the others: - A. DATEADD: Shifts the context back 30 days but doesn‚Äôt create a rolling range‚Äîit only moves the window, so you‚Äôd get sales for a single day, not 31 days. - C. DATESMTD: Returns month-to-date totals, which reset at the start of each month‚Äînot a rolling 31-day window. - D. DISTINCTCOUNT(Date[Date]) = 31: This is a filter condition, not a valid way to define a rolling window. It doesn‚Äôt guarantee the correct 31-day range.
Monsta Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
B is the right answer.
b9e3c84 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
The expresion B Max(Date[]-30) is wrong
Question 160
ID: 79434
You are creating a report in Power BI Desktop. You load a data extract that includes a free text field named coll. You need to analyze the frequency distribution of the string lengths in col1. The solution must not affect the size of the model. What should you do?

Options

  • A. In the report, add a DAX calculated column that calculates the length of col1
  • B. In the report, add a DAX function that calculates the average length of col1
  • C. From Power Query Editor, add a column that calculates the length of col1
  • D. From Power Query Editor, change the distribution for the Column profile to group by length for col1

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
Muffinshow Selected: D üëç 140 N/A
Wrong answer, A will affect the size of the model as would C. B doesn't give you enough information about the distribution (just the average) D is the right answer.
lukelin08 Selected: D üëç 83 N/A
Its D, this can easily be tested by going to Power Query Editor > View > Column Profile > distribution graph, click the three little dots and select group by text length. This will allow you to view the distribution of text length within the column
Jonagan üëç 17 N/A
Why do you think that aggregating in the PowerQuery size will not influence the size of the datamodel? its getting smaller isnt it? Measures are the only solutions that does not influence the datamodel. They require CPU but but does not store additional data or does not reduce the data in the model
eloomis üëç 7 N/A
The problem is this method doesn't make the distribution analyzable in the report, which I think is what the question is getting at. It will show you the distribution but you need a dax measure to place in your report to visualize that. I would go with option B as it creates a measure which you can use in the report, and it doesn't contribute to the size of the model as with A.
miro26 üëç 2 N/A
Make sure your column type is not "variant" ;)
HemantGorle üëç 2 N/A
D is correct and it can be tested by following step mentioned by Lukelin08
Hoeishetmogelijk üëç 2 N/A
I agree completely!
rcaliandro Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
for me is D. From Power Query Editor, change the distribution for the Column profile to group by length for col1
GPerez73 üëç 2 N/A
I agree
Datanoob101 Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
Upon a little research it turns out that calculated columns=larger data models. Option A & C: both introduce a new column. Will affect the size of the model. Option B: As muffin show and mubarakbabs stated above, it doesn't give us enough info (only avg) Ans must be D.
Question 161
ID: 146997
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains the resources shown in the following table. You create a new dashboard that uses row-level security (RLS) filters. You define a new role named Consultants. To which resource can you assign the Consultants role?

Options

  • A. Group2
  • B. Team1
  • C. Sales reports
  • D. Group1

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Endeetheanalyst üëç 19 N/A
Sales Report
627628c Selected: A üëç 10 N/A
A. Group 2. Per Microsoft Learn, here's why: "You can use the following groups to set up row-level security: Distribution Group Mail-enabled Group Microsoft Entra Security Group Note that Microsoft 365 groups aren't supported and can't be added to any roles." https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/security/service-admin-row-level-security Because of this, it should be Group 2.
El_Montasser89 üëç 3 N/A
Answer is A! https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/security/service-admin-row-level-security#add-members
LuluSkyy üëç 3 N/A
I agree the answer is sales report
irena.petkovich Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
You can use the following groups to set up row level security. Distribution Group Mail-enabled Group Security Group Note, however, that Office 365 groups are not supported and cannot be added to any roles.
desibaby09 Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
Sales reports RLS is implemented at the dataset level within Power BI workspaces.
lmml_et Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/security/service-admin-row-level-security#manage-security-on-your-model
Davery Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
Roles are assigned in PowerBI Service which means the answer must be C sales reports
Lulu_2022 Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
The correct answer is: C. Sales reports ‚úÖ Why this is correct: In Power BI, row-level security (RLS) roles ‚Äî like your Consultants role ‚Äî are assigned at the dataset level, which resides within a Power BI workspace. In this case, Sales reports is the Power BI workspace that contains the dataset and dashboard, making it the only valid resource where you can assign the role. ‚ùå Why the others don‚Äôt work: A. Group2: A mail-enabled group ‚Äî not a valid target for RLS role assignment. B. Team1: A Microsoft Teams org-wide team ‚Äî not a Power BI workspace or dataset. D. Group1: A Microsoft 365 group ‚Äî again, not a dataset or workspace.
5bf040d Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
In the Power BI service, you can add a member to the role by typing in the email address or name of the user or security group. You can't add Groups created in Power BI. You can add members external to your organization. In the Power BI Service, you can create workspaces and groups to organize and share reports, dashboards, and datasets. However, these Power BI workspace groups (or app workspace groups) are not the same as security groups (e.g., Microsoft Entra Security Groups, Distribution Groups, or Mail-enabled Groups). Power BI workspace groups (created in the Power BI Service) cannot be assigned to RLS roles. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/security/service-admin-row-level-security
Question 162
ID: 147094
You create a Power BI report named Summary1. You discover that Summary1 is slow. You run Performance analyzer to identify performance metrics for Summary1. Which two metrics display the execution duration in Performance analyzer? Each correct answer present part of the solution. NOTE: Each correct answer is worth one point.

Options

  • A. Top Operations
  • B. DAX query
  • C. Server requests
  • D. Dependencies
  • E. Visual display

Answer

Suggested Answer:
BE
Ash_34 Selected: BE üëç 3 N/A
Answer is correct!
jaume Selected: BE üëç 2 N/A
DAX query and Visual Display are the metrics available in Performance Analyzer
Lulu_2022 Selected: BE üëç 1 N/A
DAX Query This shows how long it takes Power BI to execute the DAX query behind a visual ‚Äî from the moment the query is sent to the engine until the first row of results is returned. Visual Display This measures the time it takes to render the visual on the report canvas after the data is retrieved ‚Äî essentially the client-side rendering time.
sroumi Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
Correct Answer: ‚úÖ Sales reports (Power BI workspace) Why? RLS roles can only be assigned to Power BI workspaces where the dataset is published. The Viewer role assigned to consultants in the "Sales reports" workspace allows them to access reports, but RLS filters their data further based on the "Consultants" role definition.
ChopChop007 Selected: BE üëç 1 N/A
Dax Query Visual Display
omath Selected: BE üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: B. DAX query ‚Üí ‚úÖ Yes, shows execution duration. E. Visual display ‚Üí ‚úÖ Yes, shows execution duration. * Why not the others: A. Top Operations ‚Üí Not part of Performance Analyzer; that‚Äôs from DAX Studio. ‚ùå C. Server requests ‚Üí Not shown in Performance Analyzer; that‚Äôs more of a network diagnostic. ‚ùå D. Dependencies ‚Üí Not a Performance Analyzer metric. ‚ùå
Odidepse Selected: BE üëç 1 N/A
Dax and Visual Display from https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-performance-analyzer . Excerpt from the link: Each visual's log information includes the time spent (duration) to complete the following categories of tasks: DAX query - If a DAX query was required, this is the time between the visual sending the query and Analysis Services returning the results. Visual display - This is the time required for the visual to draw on the screen, including the time required to retrieve any web images or geocoding. Other - This is the time required by the visual for preparing queries, waiting for other visuals to complete, or performing other background processing. Evaluated parameters (preview) - This is the time spent evaluating the field parameters within a visual. Learn more about field parameters (preview).
Lulu_2022 Selected: BE üëç 1 N/A
The Performance Analyzer in Power BI breaks down the time it takes to render a visual into key components: Metric What it measures DAX query Time spent executing the DAX query against the data model Visual display Time spent rendering the visual on the report canvas (client-side rendering) These two metrics directly reflect the execution duration of a visual ‚Äî helping you pinpoint whether the slowness is due to backend query logic or frontend rendering.

ID: 147014

Odidepse üëç 2 N/A
First is correct, I think second one should be Change cross-filter direction (to both) as the first step as required. Deleting many to one relationship could be necessary on specific scenarios to resolve errors, but before you could do this, first step is to enable bi directional filtering which means Change the cross-filter direction to "Both", same also with Define the relationship as active, cant do this unless you change the hange cross-filter direction and set it to both to enable bi-directional filtering. Once you Change cross-filter direction to "Both" that is the only time you can efine the relationship as active or removing delete many-to-one relationships if it gives exception error.

Question 164
ID: 147006
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model that contains a table named Item. The Item table contains a column named Quantity. You need to create a DAX query that meets the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ The rank of items must be calculated according to the values in Quantity. ‚Ä¢ Ranking must NOT be skipped if two or more items have the same value in Quantity. ‚Ä¢ If an item is unfiltered, the total of Quantity must display a blank value. How should you complete the DAX formula? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
hatem.ayed üëç 4 N/A
HASONEVALUE garantiza que la f√≥rmula se ejecute √∫nicamente cuando haya un solo valor de Item seleccionado. Esto evita que se devuelva un valor de clasificaci√≥n cuando no se ha seleccionado ning√∫n elemento, cumpliendo con el requisito de mostrar un valor en blanco si no se ha filtrado ning√∫n elemento. DENSE se asegura de que, si dos o m√°s elementos tienen la misma cantidad, no se omitan n√∫meros en la clasificaci√≥n, lo cual era otro de los requisitos.
nelrosell üëç 4 N/A
Correct Answer: HASONEVALUE, DENSE
nammm112 üëç 3 N/A
Wrong. It should be HASONEVALUE and DENSE
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: HASONEVALUE DENSE * Explanation: - If an item is unfiltered, the total of Quantity must display blank ‚Üí we wrap the ranking logic in an IF( HASONEVALUE( ‚Ä¶ ), ‚Ä¶ ) so that totals return BLANK. - Ranking must NOT be skipped if two or more items have the same value ‚Üí that means we need Dense ranking (not the default Skip ranking). * This ensures: - Items are ranked by Quantity. - Equal quantities share the same rank, and the next rank is consecutive (no gaps). - Totals (when no single item is selected) return BLANK.
Lulu_2022 üëç 1 N/A
it will return a blank when no single item is selected ‚Äî for example, in a total row or when multiple items are in context. That‚Äôs exactly what HASONEVALUE() is designed to do: it checks whether the current filter context contains only one distinct value for Item[ItemID]. If not, the IF statement skips the RANKX() and returns blank. This is useful when you want to suppress totals or avoid showing misleading rankings when multiple items are visible. If you‚Äôd prefer to show something else (like ‚ÄúN/A‚Äù or a default rank) instead of blank, I can help you tweak the logic. Want to explore that?
0f4908c üëç 1 N/A
Selected Value Example = SELECTEDVALUE(Products[ProductName], BLANK()) ? HASONEVALUE need IF
jaume üëç 1 N/A
RANKX(<table>, <expression>[, <value>[, <order>[, <ties>]]]) <expression> to evaluate for ranking (within the <table>) <value> is optional; if omitted, current row's value in <expression> is used <order> (optional) to set sort order (ASC, DESC) <ties> is also optional and determines how ties are handled SKIP: skips rank for ties (e.g ranks 1,2,2,4) DENSE does not skip ranks for ties (e.g. ranks 1,2,2,3)
Question 165
ID: 147016
You have a Power BI semantic model that connects to a streaming data source. The data source is updated frequently. You need to create a Power BI report that meets the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Supports real-time analytics ‚Ä¢ Minimizes performance impact on the data source ‚Ä¢ Displays the most recent data without performing a data refresh Which connectivity mode should you use for the dataset?

Options

  • A. DirectQuery mode
  • B. import mode
  • C. LiveConnect mode
  • D. push mode

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
rcaliandro Selected: A üëç 8 N/A
real-time analytics => DirectQuery
0f4908c üëç 4 N/A
Displays the most recent data without performing a data refresh-->Push mode
drigotto8 Selected: D üëç 4 N/A
Push mode: This mode allows data to be pushed directly into Power BI from a streaming data source. It is designed for real-time analytics and does not require a data refresh because the data is continuously updated as it is pushed into Power BI. This minimizes the performance impact on the data source since the data is sent directly to Power BI without querying the source repeatedly.
SushiPowerBI_175 Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Push datasets allow streaming updates without refresh and support real-time visuals.
ChopChop007 üëç 3 N/A
Direct Query.
Lulu_2022 Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Why push mode is the best fit: Real-time analytics: Push mode is designed specifically for streaming scenarios where data is sent into Power BI as it arrives. No refresh needed: Visuals update automatically when new data is pushed ‚Äî no scheduled or manual refresh required. Minimal impact on source: Since Power BI receives the data passively (it doesn‚Äôt query the source), it avoids putting load on the original system
nyanlinhtike.nlh Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Correct answer is D
Odidepse Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Pushmode handles frequent data updates without requiring a data refresh. Cannot be direct query, as stated on the requirement '‚Ä¢ Displays the most recent data without performing a data refresh' direct query it requires querying the data source each time the report is viewed or interacted with. 100%
Pritch Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
D. push mode https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/refresh-data Push semantic models don't contain a formal definition of a data source, so they **don't require you to perform a data refresh in Power BI**. You refresh them by pushing your data into the semantic model through an external service or process, such as Azure Stream Analytics. This is a **common approach for real-time analytics** with Power BI.
ak57 üëç 2 N/A
I think it's Push mode based on this article:
Question 166
ID: 147013
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model that contains a table named Opportunity. The Opportunity table contains a column named Qualification. The Qualification column contains values between 0 and 1. You need to build a new measure to score the opportunities on a scale of low. medium, and high. How should you complete the DAX formula? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
P_BKTX üëç 10 N/A
IF is correct answer https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/if-function-dax check last example
b9e3c84 üëç 4 N/A
The correct answer is IF, HIGH and MEDIUM
miloszmiloszz üëç 3 N/A
I will use IF instead of IF.EAGER due to values that are used in true/false arguments. If there would be more complex values (another formulas, references to columns etc.) I will prefer IF.EAGER. See https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/if-eager-function-dax -cdot above Examples part.
Endeetheanalyst üëç 3 N/A
Answer is correct. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/if-eager-function-dax
SylUK üëç 2 N/A
The IF.EAGER,HIGH, MEDIUM are the correct answer: In Power BI's DAX language, the primary difference between the "IF" and "IF.EAGER" functions lies in their evaluation strategy: "IF" only evaluates the expression corresponding to the true or false condition based on the logical test, while "IF.EAGER" always evaluates both expressions regardless of the condition, which can sometimes lead to performance improvements in specific scenarios where both branches need to be calculated regardless of the outcome. See this link:https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/if-eager-function-dax
nelrosell üëç 2 N/A
IF is also fine
1CY1 üëç 2 N/A
I'm going with just 'IF'. IF.Eager seems to only be required for variant data type comparison... The IF.EAGER function can return a variant data type if value_if_true and value_if_false are of different data types, but the function attempts to return a single data type if both value_if_true and value_if_false are of numeric data types. In the latter case, the IF.EAGER function will implicitly convert data types to accommodate both values.
drigotto8 üëç 1 N/A
I would also answer IF
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. IF 2. High 3. Medium * Explanation: This nested IF structure ensures that all values between 0 and 1 are categorized correctly: - < 0.5 ‚Üí Low - > 0.7 ‚Üí High - 0.5 to 0.7 ‚Üí Medium * Completed DAX Formula: Sales Qualification = IF ( 'Opportunity'[Qualification] < 0.5, "Low", IF ( 'Opportunity'[Qualification] > 0.7, "High", "Medium" ) )
jaume üëç 1 N/A
I would vote for the IF not IF.EAGER as I cannot see the point to use second one. Then HIGH & MEDIUM
Question 167
ID: 147019
HOTSPOT - You have an organization dimension named DimOrganizations. You have four related tables as shown in the following exhibit. Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
rcaliandro üëç 9 N/A
The answer is correct. It is a snowflakeschema and DimOrgSubVertical is the only table that supports a hierarchy model for DimOrgVertical
LuluSkyy üëç 6 N/A
can someone please explain why DimOrgSubVertical supports a hierarchy for the model?
jaume üëç 2 N/A
A degenerate dimension refers to a dimension key in a fact table that does not have its own dimension table. Junk Dimension is a dimension table in a data warehouse that combines several low cardinality flags and indicators to improve the efficiency of queries. A role-playing dimension refers to a single dimension table that is utilized multiple times within a fact table, each time representing a different logical role or perspective. The one in the exhibit is a SNOWFLAKE SCHEMA (not dimension) as the fact table is related to dim tables which can be linked to other dim tables. DimOrgSubVertical is the only table supporting hierarchy model for DimOrgVertical (DimOrganization could support hierarchy for DimSubVrtical)
MonikaStop üëç 2 N/A
I agree
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. snowflake - Here, the organizational hierarchy is split across multiple related tables (DimOrgVertical ‚Üí DimOrgSubVertical ‚Üí DimOrganizations). - This is a snowflake dimension (a normalized dimension structure). 2. DimOrgSubVertical - The hierarchy flows from DimOrgVertical ‚Üí DimOrgSubVertical ‚Üí DimOrganizations. - The table that directly supports the hierarchy for DimOrgVertical is DimOrgSubVertical, since it links Vertical to SubVertical and then down to Organizations.
0ab376f üëç 1 N/A
co ask
Question 168
ID: 146906
You have a Power BI semantic model that contains item, price, and country data. The data is displayed in a report that uses filters. You need to calculate the average item price for a given country. The solution must support the existing filters. Which type of quick measure should you use?

Options

  • A. Total for category (filters applied)
  • B. Average per category
  • C. Rolling average
  • D. Weighted average per category

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
Endeetheanalyst üëç 3 N/A
B is the answer.
jiheneB Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/transform-model/desktop-quick-measures
jaume Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
This is the only solution calculating the average as requested. Other options are calculating "rolling" and "weighted" average or total price. Since ew must keep existing filters, there is no need to use CALCULATE function there
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Why this is the best choice: "Average per category" is designed to calculate the average of a measure (like item price) within each group (like country), while respecting all existing filters in the report. It dynamically adjusts based on slicers or visual-level filters, so if a user selects a specific country, the average reflects only that country‚Äôs data.
uno96 üëç 2 N/A
i am sure D because The Weighted average per category quick measure ensures the correct calculation of the average item price for a specific country, supporting existing filters and maintaining data context.
shedi13 üëç 1 N/A
I would say thats A, beacuse you can change summarization on total to average
desibaby09 Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
it says average ITEM price which could want to include the number of items in the formula. The answer choice B does not allow us to use that information
Jayaruwan Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
B is the correct answer. It wants to calculate average not the total
rcaliandro Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
B. Average per category
omath Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: B. Average per category * Explanation: - We want the average item price for a given country, while still respecting any filters applied in the report. - The Average per category quick measure calculates the average of a measure (in this case, Price) grouped by a category (in this case, Country). - It automatically respects the existing filter context in the report, so if we filter by a specific country, the calculation will reflect only that country‚Äôs data. * Why not the others? A. Total for category (filters applied): Returns totals, not averages. C. Rolling average: Used for time-based smoothing (e.g., last 3 months), not relevant here. D. Weighted average per category: Requires a weighting factor (like quantity), which isn‚Äôt part of the requirement.
Question 169
ID: 134819
You have a Power BI data model that contains two tables named Sales and Date. The Sales table contains three measures named Order Quantity, Product Cost, and Sales Amount. You need to create the visual shown in the following exhibit. In which section of the Fields well should you place the measures?

Options

  • A. Columns
  • B. Rows
  • C. Values
  • D. Drill through

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
Datapassion üëç 24 N/A
Correct answer is C To have the same exact matrix, you need to put the different measures in the "Values" well and then to go to the format pane of your matrix and select "Switch values to rows" under the "Values" section.
maymia87 üëç 9 N/A
Here's a tutorial https://datasavvy.me/2017/08/10/you-can-now-put-values-on-rows-in-power-bi/
Piotrek_PL üëç 6 N/A
Make sure you got a matrix type of visual. It looks like you had just a table.
Florinuca üëç 4 N/A
The correct answer is C - Values. Firstly, this type of visualization is a MATRIX. If you do a simple test in PowerBI Desktop, you can see that in the "Rows" section, we can't add measures! Most likely, the names of the measures in the rows of the matrix appear because the measures were put in "fields parameteres" that generated a Calculated Table, and the actual values of the measures appear by adding the measures (not from the Calculated Table) in the "Values" section.
Margaft üëç 4 N/A
C. Values
INDEAVR üëç 3 N/A
It is not possible to put a measure in Columns. You can only put a measure in Values. However, putting the measures in Values is not going to produce the same visual. Neither of the answers is correct in my opinion.
syjang_0421 Selected: C üëç 3 N/A
Values
JustdoBI üëç 3 N/A
Values
6f38739 üëç 3 N/A
Should be Values
MITZ619 Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
c. Value
Question 170
ID: 122843
You have a Power BI model that contains the following data. The Date table relates to the Sales table by using the Date columns. The model contains the following DAX measure. Total Sales = SUM(Sales[Sale]) You need to create another measure named Previous Quarter to display the sales one quarter before the selected period. Which DAX calculation should you use?

Options

  • A. CALCULATE ( [Total Sales], DATEADD (Date[Date], -1, QUARTER ) )
  • B. CALCULATE ( [Total Sales], DATESQTD (Date[Date] ) )
  • C. TOTALQTD ( [Total Sales], Date[Date] )
  • D. CALCULATE ( [Total Sales], PARALLELPERIOD (Date[Date], 1, QUARTER ) )

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
tranquanghuy2111 üëç 20 N/A
DATEADD is correct. PARALLELPERIOD also calculate one quarter before, but the out come is the total sales of three months of previous quarter not only one day or one month of previous quarter
Koalakueh Selected: A üëç 9 N/A
we can use PARALLELPERIOD() as well. It's just that the option for that is 1 year later rather than 1 year earlier
ZillowGosia üëç 7 N/A
A is correct.
Abhi_1526 Selected: A üëç 3 N/A
-1 so A
Mal42 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Given answer is right
Dani_eL Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
DATEADD ( from date, direction(before/after), interval (in days, months, quarters, years) )
rcaliandro Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A - CALCULATE ( [Total Sales], DATEADD (Date[Date], -1, QUARTER ) )
jaume Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
B. QTD would return "Quarter To Date" result not previous year C. Again it's about QTD D. if you doubt about the PARALLELPERIOD, note the step is 1 not -1 so it would be not the previous quarter but next one A. with DATADD function using a negative (-1) step, we are referring to the previous quarter
TestSavvySage123 üëç 1 N/A
Option A is correct Here is chatgpt solution::--Previous Quarter = CALCULATE ( [Total Sales], DATEADD ( Date[Date], -1, QUARTER ) )
LeeTheRed üëç 1 N/A
Good observation!
Question 171
ID: 122841
HOTSPOT - You have a query named All Sales that imports sales data into a Power BI model. You plan to create a star schema by separating columns into separate queries and performing further transformations. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Use All Sales as the source for three other queries named Sales Fact, Product Dimension, and Customer Dimension. ‚Ä¢ Minimize maintenance effort. What should you do to create the Sales Fact query, and for which query should you clear Enable load? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
tranquanghuy2111 üëç 39 N/A
Reference is the most common way to replicate origninal query. Clear "enable load" to "All Sales" cause the data of this query is now loaded to other table. It is not necessary to load it to Report view anymore
juliettelaurier üëç 27 N/A
The question provides the answer. We are referencing All Sales for all three tables, and then we are clearing Enable load for All Sales to reduce the data model and increase performance. Referencing will reduce maintenance because the three tables will be derived from the original data and we can keep the transformations to the source data without having to modify three queries.
cs3122 üëç 2 N/A
totally agree, good explanation
Dsbuff üëç 2 N/A
The answer is correct.
rcaliandro üëç 1 N/A
The answer seems to be correct
0e18c76 üëç 1 N/A
Totally agree. Reference the All sales query All sales
0e18c76 üëç 1 N/A
Right answer.
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: To create Sales Fact: Reference the All Sales query. - Using Reference instead of Duplicate ensures that any changes to the source query (All Sales) automatically flow through to the dependent queries (Sales Fact, Product Dimension, Customer Dimension). This minimizes maintenance effort because you only maintain transformations in one place. Clear Enable data load for: All Sales - The All Sales query is just a staging query (an intermediate step). It feeds the fact and dimension queries but doesn‚Äôt need to be loaded into the model itself. Disabling load prevents redundant data from being stored in the model, improving performance and keeping the schema clean.
539d541 üëç 1 N/A
Answer is correct
Question 172
ID: 117415
HOTSPOT - You are creating a Power BI model to analyze inventory. You load data into three tables named Date, Product, and Inventory. The Inventory table relates to the Date and Product tables by using one-to-many relationships. Inventory data is recorded daily with no exceptions. The correct inventory quantity for a given product in a month is the last recorded value for that month. You need to write a DAX measure that will show the correct inventory value when a user analyzes inventory by year, month, or date. How should you complete the measure? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
pverde üëç 28 N/A
I believe the answer is correct
andrewkravchuk97 üëç 12 N/A
Calculate LastNonBlankValue LASTDATE will NOT work. Date - is a date table and it contains all days of the calendar month continuously so it will always return the last day of the month even if there is no inventory records. "The correct inventory quantity for a given product in a month is the last recorded value for that month.". That's why we should use LastNonBlankValue instead.
blmthmn üëç 10 N/A
It also says 'Inventory data is recorded daily with no exceptions.' so I concluded that each day would have an inventory record.
a22775 üëç 7 N/A
CALCULATE LASTDATE It isn't MAX because that would returns an scalar instead of a table. https://www.sqlbi.com/blog/marco/2013/10/22/difference-between-lastdate-and-max-for-semi-additive-measures-in-dax/
EwoutBI üëç 7 N/A
LASTNONBLANKVALUE also requires an expression though. https://learn.microsoft.com/nl-nl/dax/lastnonblankvalue-function-dax
rgabage üëç 6 N/A
The answer is correct
kelvin3105 üëç 5 N/A
I think this questions is not well explained. Let me say why ( from brazil, sorry if I write wrong): 1. That is form to create a calendar table based in the dates of the fact table, for example: if I create based on the fact table, the last date will be the last date of the fact table. 2. Other way of create a calendar table is just to put the days of a number of years that you want, so, in this case the last date will be the last date of the calendar table and not the last date of the fact table. So, in my opinion it is better annul this question, or consider lastnonblankvalue and lastdate correct.
SRL_Student üëç 3 N/A

yep question is confusing indeed
Aero_1898 üëç 2 N/A

  • A. Merge columns
  • B. Transpose
  • C. Unpivot columns
  • D. Pivot column

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C

ope, scratch that. I see that it's unpivot now
Igetmyrole üëç 5 N/A
C is correct. To shape the query to display the required three columns (month, sales,year), you should select the "Unpivot columns" option in Power Query Editor. This will transfer the data from its current columnar structure (where each year is a separate column) into a tabular format with separate rows for each combination of Month, Sales, and Year.

Question 174
ID: 117413
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI model that contains the following data. The Date table relates to the Sales table by using the Date columns. You need to create a calculated table that will contain the following: ‚Ä¢ A row for each year ‚Ä¢ A column that contains the total sales per year How should you complete the DAX calculation? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
pverde üëç 31 N/A
Agreed with SUMMARIZE - Date[Year]
6f38739 üëç 6 N/A
Guys please read the question, you you chose date you will have many rows... A column that contains the total sales per year
SomeAzureGuyincube üëç 5 N/A
I've recreated mock data through ChatGPT and in PowerBI. I've tested the following dax measure : - SalesSummary = SUMMARIZE(Sales,Date[Date],"Sales",SUM(Sales[Sales])) - SalesSummary = SUMMARIZE(Sales,Date[Year],"Sales",SUM(Sales[Sales])) First dax measures creates a table that has many rows as many sales in that month have been sold and does not respond to "A row for each year" requirement. By using Date[Year], you have a summarized Table which you have ONLY one row per each year with the value as sum Something like this : 2024 | 8000,00$ 2023 | 5000,00$ Rollup and Select Columns in first menu are wrong as they don't match parameters. So, Correct answer is *SalesSummary = SUMMARIZE(Sales,Date[Year],"Sales",SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]))* (don't mind the names used for mockup data)
LeeLee_105 üëç 4 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dax/summarize-function-dax
LeeLee_105 üëç 4 N/A
Ans is correct
ZillowGosia üëç 1 N/A
How this can be correct if Date[Year] is integer?
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. SUMMARIZE 2. Date[Year] * Explanation; - SUMMARIZE: Creates a table grouped by the specified columns (Date[Year]). - Because the Date table is related to Sales by the Date column, the aggregation works correctly.
Shirl_Nina üëç 1 N/A
Agreed
1CY1 üëç 1 N/A
Correct answer -> SUMMARIZE, Date[Year]
1CY1 üëç 1 N/A
The ROLLUP function is used exclusively within SUMMARIZE. E.g. SUMMARIZE ( Sales, ROLLUP ( 'Date'[Calendar Year] ), "Year total", ISSUBTOTAL ( 'Date'[Calendar Year] ), "Amount", [Sales Amount] )
Question 175
ID: 117375
You have a Power BI model that contains a table named Date. The Date table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Date ‚Ä¢ Fiscal Year ‚Ä¢ Fiscal Quarter ‚Ä¢ Month Name ‚Ä¢ Calendar Year ‚Ä¢ Week Number ‚Ä¢ Month Number ‚Ä¢ Calendar Quarter You need to create a calculated table based on the Date table. The calculated table must contain only unique combinations of values for Calendar Year, Calendar Quarter, and Calendar Month. Which DAX function should you include in the table definition?

Options

  • A. ADDCOLUMNS
  • B. CALCULATE
  • C. SUMMARIZE
  • D. DATATABLE

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
Pocu üëç 86 N/A
I wanna say that again. Comment and vote carefully before you have actually done some research otherwise It will cause confusion to other people. The answer is Summarize. UniqueCalendarTable = SUMMARIZE( Date, 'Date'[Calendar Year], 'Date'[Calendar Quarter], 'Date'[Month Name] )
AyoJose üëç 17 N/A
"Comment and vote carefully before you have actually done some research" or after you've actually done some research?
Badadadiiii Selected: C üëç 12 N/A
Should be Summarized
pverde Selected: C üëç 7 N/A
I think it should be SUMMARIZE SUMMARIZE: "Creates a summary of the input table grouped by the specified columns." ADDCOLUMNS: "Returns a table with new columns specified by the DAX expressions." Based on this, using SUMMARIZE will give us the unique combination we want and don't need to use DAX expressions to create the calculated table.
tranquanghuy2111 üëç 5 N/A
Nope, ADDCOLUMNS will add additional column to given table. Therefore, outcome is given table with all its original columns and the added ones. But the question only requires 3 columns. --> SUMMARIZE is correct answer here
LeeLee_105 Selected: C üëç 4 N/A
https://youtu.be/VurpXBcbrT0
Rhugved Selected: C üëç 3 N/A
Summarize is the correct answer!
SIH007 üëç 3 N/A
Thank you for your solution, Pocu, it helped a lot!
Shirl_Nina üëç 3 N/A
ADDCOLUMNS is correct. It Adds calculated columns to the given table or table expression whereas SUMMARIZE Returns a summary table for the requested totals over a set of groups.
sergeyitaly üëç 3 N/A
Addcolumns does not create a new table, but Summarize does create it
