Question 297
ID: 146926
DRAG DROP - You use Power Query Editor to load two queries named Query1 and Query2. Query1 results in the following error. Query2 results in the following error. Which type of error occurred for each query? To answer, drag the appropriate error types to the correct queries. Each error type may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
rcaliandro üëç 7 N/A
Answer is correct
P_BKTX üëç 6 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-query/dealing-with-errors
jaume üëç 5 N/A
Query 2 --> Step-level Error: a step-level error prevents the query from loading and displays the error components in a yellow pane Query 2 --> Cell-level Error: a cell-level error won't prevent the query from loading but displays error values as Error in the cell.
P_BKTX üëç 4 N/A
Correct
Mi4as üëç 1 N/A
In Power Query, you can encounter two types of errors: Step-level errors (most common error message text starts with Expression.Error: bla-bla) Cell-level errors (starts with DataFormat.Error: bla-bla or Formula bla-bla) https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-query/dealing-with-errors
Question 298
ID: 156204
HOTSPOT - You use Microsoft Power BI Desktop to review the data shown in the following exhibit. Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Aeffat17 üëç 22 N/A
I would suggest : 1. Auto Date/Time Auto Date/Time is a Power BI feature that automatically creates a Date Hierarchy (Year, Quarter, Month, Day) when a Date column is present. In the provided screenshot, the Date table has an automatically generated hierarchy, indicating that Auto Date/Time was enabled. Marking a table as a Date table disables Auto Date/Time, removing any automatically generated date hierarchies. 2. The MonthEndDate Date Hierarchy from the Data Table Auto Date/Time was used, removing it will delete automatically created hierarchies (e.g., MonthEndDate Date Hierarchy).
Jasmine121 üëç 4 N/A
It's "Mark as date table". There is a typo in the context.
Lulu_2022 üëç 2 N/A
1Ô∏è‚É£ You used: auto date/time This refers to Power BI‚Äôs Auto Date/Time feature, which automatically creates hidden date tables and hierarchies behind the scenes when you load a date field. It‚Äôs commonly used when: You haven‚Äôt created a custom Date table You want to quickly use time intelligence features without building a full calendar table 2Ô∏è‚É£ Configure "Mark as Date Table" setting for the Date table will remove: the MonthEndDate date hierarchy from the Date table When you mark a table as a Date table, Power BI disables the Auto Date/Time feature for that column. As a result: The built-in date hierarchies (like Year > Quarter > Month > Day) are removed You‚Äôll now rely on your custom Date table for all time intelligence It does not remove your own columns like MonthStartDate or the Date table itself
ca63a55 üëç 1 N/A
Date Hierarchy- Es importante tener en cuenta que, al marcar una tabla como una tabla de fechas, Power BI Desktop quita la tabla de fechas integrada (creada autom√°ticamente). Y los objetos visuales o expresiones DAX que haya creado anteriormente en funci√≥n de esas tablas integradas ya no funcionar√°n correctamente. https://learn.microsoft.com/es-es/power-bi/transform-model/desktop-date-tables#benefits-of-setting-your-own-date-table
ca63a55 üëç 1 N/A
Quick Measures / Date Hierarchy https://learn.microsoft.com/es-es/power-bi/transform-model/desktop-date-tables
SylUK üëç 1 N/A
Given answer is correct: Quick measures and The MonthStartDate column
Jasmine121 üëç 1 N/A
Isn't it hierarchy?
Aeffat17 üëç 1 N/A
what will be the answer?
Mi4as üëç 1 N/A
It should be "Auto Date/Time" and "the MonthEndDate date hierarchy from the Data table" First, it should be "Mark as Date table" rather than "Mask as Date table". If marked, the Power BI removes the auto-generated date hierarchies not only from the marked table, but also from the relationship field of another table (only that one date field, not all related table fields).
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. auto date/time - Since the Date table already contains detailed columns like MonthStartDate, MonthEndDate, MonthSortNumber, etc., this is not the auto date/time feature (which generates hidden date tables with only basic hierarchies). - It‚Äôs also not quick measures (those generate DAX, not tables). - The correct answer is: auto date/time was used originally to generate a hidden date table, but here you‚Äôve instead created a proper Date table. 2. the MonthEndDate date hierarchy from the Data table - When you mark a table as the official Date table, Power BI removes the auto-generated date hierarchies (those hidden auto date/time tables). - It does not remove the Date table itself, nor any of its columns. - So the correct answer is: the MonthEndDate date hierarchy from the Data table (i.e., the auto date/time hierarchies).
Question 299
ID: 156917
You have a Power BI semantic model that contains the following data. You need to create a solution that meets the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Presents transaction amount totals for each month for the current and prior year ‚Ä¢ Follows the star schema modeling approach ‚Ä¢ Minimizes the data model size Which three actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Options

  • A. Create one-to-many relationships between the tables.
  • B. In the Transactions query, delete the TransactionID column.
  • C. In the Date query, group by MonthNumber.
  • D. In the Transactions query, group by AccountID and MonthStartDate for TransactionDate. Aggregate by summing the TransAmt column.
  • E. In the Transactions query, add a column that contains the MonthStartDate value for TransactionDate.
  • F. Create many-to-many relationships between the tables.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
ABD
5bf040d Selected: ABD üëç 3 N/A
I believe E is not correct because adding MonthStartDate to the Transactions table would increase the data size, and this information is already available in the Date table.
32c0a0b Selected: ADE üëç 2 N/A
I'll go for ADE, As with out creating a start month date column we cannot group or aggregate the table: So its: 1) Create Start month date column 2) Group or aggregate 3) create relationships
SylUK Selected: ABD üëç 2 N/A
A B D are the correct answers . E and F go against the requirement .
Lulu_2022 Selected: ABE üëç 2 N/A
This are the correFirst, you should create one-to-many relationships between the tables. This aligns with best practices for building a star schema ‚Äî the fact table should link to dimension tables via one-to-many relationships for optimal performance and clarity. Second, in the Transactions query, you should delete the TransactionID column. Since you're not analyzing or filtering based on TransactionID, and it's likely a high-cardinality field, removing it helps minimize model size and improves performance. Third, still within the Transactions query, you should add a new column that contains the MonthStartDate value for the TransactionDate. This helps group transactions by month and prepares your data for efficient time-based analysis, like comparing this year to last year.
kai_data Selected: AB üëç 2 N/A
Selecting D without E, makes no sense as transactions query have no MonthStartDate to aggregate on. But E indeed increase the size of the model.
BIT2024 Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
for me is ADE
omath Selected: ABD üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A,B,D A. Create one-to-many relationships between the tables - In a star schema, fact tables (Transactions) connect to dimension tables (Date, Account) via one-to-many relationships. - This is the canonical design pattern for Power BI semantic models. B. In the Transactions query, delete the TransactionID column - TransactionID is a high-cardinality, surrogate key that is not needed for aggregations. - Removing it reduces model size significantly without affecting reporting requirements D. In the Transactions query, group by AccountID and MonthStartDate for TransactionDate. Aggregate by summing the TransAmt column - This reduces the row count in the fact table by pre-aggregating to the monthly level. - Since the requirement is only monthly totals (not daily transactions), this is the best way to minimize model size.
Trixy Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
I would do in this order E -> D -> A. Add MonthStartDate to Transactions query -> aggregate Transactions query by AccountID and MonthStartDate (TeansactionID will need to be excluded in this step) -> set up one-to-many relationship between Transactions and Account on AccountID column and Transactions and Date on MonthStartDate column.
Mi4as Selected: ADE üëç 1 N/A
A-E-D. Point D will automatically do point B. Everything that is not in the group will be removed (transaction ID and transaction date), never listen to GPTchat and people without checking yourself. Impotent. Point D is impossible without point E. We need a column to aggregate data on the first day of the month and reduce the model size.
Question 300
ID: 169891
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model. You need to create a column that will contain year-over-year (YOY) revenue. The column must contain a ratio of change factor compared to the previous year's monthly revenue. How should you complete the DAX formula? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
ChrisFerko üëç 6 N/A
The answer is correct
omath üëç 2 N/A
* Answer: 1. SAMEPERIODLASTYEAR - Shifts the current filter context back exactly one year, ensuring you‚Äôre comparing the same month in the prior year. 2. DIVIDE - Safely computes the ratio (Current ‚Äì Prior) / Prior, handling divide-by-zero cases gracefully. * Why not the other options: - NEXTYEAR: Moves forward in time, not backward. - PREVIOUSYEAR: Returns the entire previous year, not the same period (month) last year. - PARALLELPERIOD: More flexible but requires specifying interval (month, quarter, year). For this scenario, SAMEPERIODLASTYEAR is the canonical and simplest choice.
Mi4as üëç 1 N/A
PREVIOUSYEAR and DIVIDE This is YoY analysis. That is, the PREVIOUSYEAR function. Why are there comments about comparing the month? The task for the full selected year and the function that will calculate the previous year to the selected year.
Question 301
ID: 105081
DRAG DROP - You use Power Query Editor to preview the data shown in the following exhibit. You need to clean and transform the query so that all the rows of data are maintained, and error values in the discount column are replaced with a discount of 0.05. The solution must minimize administrative effort. Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
RazaTheLegend üëç 63 N/A
Order is correct, we need to correct the errors first. Thus we select the column and then replace errors then change the data type.
ET_phone_home_son üëç 20 N/A
Select Discount > Replace errors with 0.05 > Set Discount type to Decimal
Asaase üëç 8 N/A
I disagree. This is better...... Select Discount > Set Discount type to Decimal > Replace errors with 0.05 Reason: practically, errors could have arisen because of wrong data type. It is best to correct the data type first (some errors may actually go away). Then you replace the remaining errors with 0.05. If you replace errors first, you totally miss out on potential corrections with the data type change
waxlyrical üëç 6 N/A
I disagree with the order; we should change data type before replacing errors. Errors may arise from changing the data type and if this is done last the errors will remain on load.
XAPT_Kft üëç 5 N/A
This order is correct: - Select the discount column - Change data type to decimal - Select Replace Errors TESTED
Pratham8285 üëç 5 N/A
Is it incorrect if I set the Discount type to Decimal before replacing the errors?
Detviler üëç 3 N/A
This was so logical. No argument for this one.
newusername üëç 3 N/A
Why do we need to change the datatype?
Arnav123 üëç 3 N/A
yes I agree because we change the data type before replacing the errors, it may result in producing an error.
Igetmyrole üëç 2 N/A
The correct three consecutive actions are: Action 1: Select the discount column. This is the column we need to transform. Action 3: From the discount column, change data type to decimal Number. This step is necessary to work with numeric values. Action 5: Select replace error to replace each error value with 0.05. This will address the requirement of replacing error values with the desired discount value. Action 2: select the price column. Selecting the price column is not relevant to the requirement of cleaning and transforming the discount column. Action 4: From the discount column, change data type to whole number. Changing the data type of the discount column to a whole number is not appropriate since the discount values are decimal numbers, and you want to replace errors with 0.05, which is not a whole number.
Question 302
ID: 146968
You have a Power BI report that contains a card. The card displays the value for year-to-date revenue. You need to ensure that screen reader users can read the value when initially interacting with the card. The value must stay updated as the dataset is refreshed. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Convert the card into a text box.
  • B. Add the value to the chart title text.
  • C. Populate the alt text with a static value.
  • D. Populate the alt text by using conditional formatting with a DAX measure.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
nelrosell üëç 4 N/A
Correct anwer but we need to move the date from row to colum bucket
jaume Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Enabling screen reader to read anything, you must use the alt text. Since "value must stay updated as the dataset is refreshed", we cannot use a static value but a dynamic one so option D instead C
Jayaruwan Selected: D üëç 3 N/A
Given answer is correct
omath Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
D. Populate the alt text by using conditional formatting with a DAX measure. This allows you to bind the alt text to a DAX measure (e.g., [YTD Revenue]), so the screen reader reads the current value every time, and it stays updated with refreshes. For accessibility in Power BI, dynamic alt text with conditional formatting is the canonical solution. It ensures screen readers announce the latest values, making reports inclusive and accurate.
Lulu_2022 Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
lt text is what screen readers use to describe visuals to users who can‚Äôt see them. By using conditional formatting with a DAX measure, you can dynamically populate the alt text with the current year-to-date revenue value. This ensures that the alt text updates automatically whenever the dataset is refreshed ‚Äî keeping it accurate and accessible.
d216393 Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
Alt text is the feature used for screen readers. As we want a solution that retrieves updated results, It has to be option D

  • C. data bars
  • D. background color

Question 305
ID: 148497
You have a Power BI report that contains the visual shown in the following exhibit. You need to make the visual more accessible to users who have color vision deficiency. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Change the font color of values in the Sales column to white.
  • B. Change the red background color to orange.
  • C. Add additional measures to the table values.
  • D. Add icons to represent the sales status of each product.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
b92fc92 üëç 9 N/A
D in my opinion
omath Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
D. Add icons to represent the sales status of each product. - When designing for accessibility in Power BI, especially for users with color vision deficiency, you need to avoid relying on color alone to convey meaning. - Icons provide a non-color visual cue (e.g., arrows, checkmarks, warning symbols). This ensures that even if a user cannot distinguish the background colors, they can still interpret the sales performance. - This aligns with accessibility best practices: never rely on color alone to convey meaning
jaume üëç 2 N/A
"color vision deficiency" so options A and B wouldn't work as it would still be about colouring different values. Icons would support people with color deficiency to get the comparison in the visual

D is correct.
LuluSkyy üëç 1 N/A
D is the correct answer
ak57 üëç 1 N/A

Question 306
ID: 148499
You have a Power BI app that contains a report named Report1. You add a new page to Report1. You need to ensure that users can view the new page. The solution must minimize administrative effort. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Update the audience in the app.
  • B. Update the app.
  • C. Update the contact information in the app.
  • D. Unpublish and create a new app.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
b92fc92 Selected: B üëç 7 N/A
B in my opinion
omath Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
B. Update the app. - When you add a new page to a report that is already published inside a Power BI app, that page will not automatically appear to end users. The app must be republished (updated) so that the new content is included in the app package. - After editing the report (adding the new page), you simply update the app from the workspace. - This republishes the app with the new page included, with minimal administrative effort.
MANANDAVEY Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
B is right
jaume Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Audience has not change so no effect in the current users. Similarly, updating contact information would no impact the content available to the app users. Option D could work as creating a new app replica (same content as original) would have same effect as simply updating the app.. but would not minimize administrative effort.
Question 307
ID: 154458
You have a Power BI semantic model that contains a table named Table1. Table1 contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ WebsiteName ‚Ä¢ URL You need to create a report named Report1 that will contain a table visual. The solution must meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Display the website name. ‚Ä¢ Enable users to navigate to the website's URL by selecting the website name. What should you use?

Options

  • A. data categories
  • B. Conditional Formatting
  • C. inline hierarchy labels
  • D. URL icons

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
gstep Selected: B üëç 5 N/A
B- need to "Enable users to navigate to the website's URL by selecting the website name"
ferben üëç 4 N/A
Exactly You have two columns "Name" and "URL" You create a table visual with only Name then you do the conditionnal formatting Name > Conditionnal formatting > web URL > based on the column URL
omath Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A. Data categories. - Setting the URL column‚Äôs data category to Web URL allows Power BI to treat it as a hyperlink. You can then display the WebsiteName column in the table, and users can click it to navigate to the site. - The data category setting is what tells Power BI how to interpret a column. By categorizing the URL column as a Web URL, you unlock hyperlink functionality and can display user-friendly names instead of raw URLs.
MANANDAVEY Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
Its B. If considering chatgpt answer its wrong
0e11c58 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Chat gpt: Data Categores To achieve the requirement where users can navigate to a website's URL by selecting the website name, you need to set the URL column to the Web URL data category in Power BI. This allows Power BI to recognize the URL as a clickable link, which can be associated with the WebsiteName column in your visual.
_jay95_ üëç 2 N/A
The requirement here is different, and option B is correct.
225401f Selected: A üëç 1 N/A

61e780a Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
B-Tested
Lulu_2022 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Correct answer: B. Conditional Formatting üß† Why this works: To make the WebsiteName column clickable and navigate to the corresponding URL, you should use Conditional Formatting ‚Üí Web URL in Power BI: Create a table visual with WebsiteName. In the Format pane, go to: Values ‚Üí Conditional formatting ‚Üí Web URL In the dialog box: Set Based on field to the URL column. This tells Power BI to treat the WebsiteName text as a hyperlink pointing to the actual URL.
AmieM Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Answer is B. One may first think that data categories is the way to go as this is the foundation of URL use, but only conditional formatting will allow for you to click a website name (that has a hidden URL) that is different than the actual URL.
Question 308
ID: 154459
You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that contains two fields named Sales and Quarter. Model1 contains a DAX measure that sums the Sales column. You need to create a report that will contain the visual shown in the following exhibit. The solution must NOT require additional DAX measures. Which type of visual should you use?

Options

  • A. ribbon chart
  • B. line chart
  • C. 100% stacked area chart
  • D. area chart

Answer

Suggested Answer:
C
be79ac3 Selected: C üëç 3 N/A
100% stacked as it is showing different segments in a 100% total
omath Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
C. 100% stacked area chart - Displays each category‚Äôs contribution as a percentage of the total at each point in time. - Matches the exhibit (0%‚Äì100% scale on Y-axis). - Does not require additional DAX measures since the visual itself handles the percentage calculation.
0e11c58 Selected: C üëç 2 N/A
Checked google
SylUK Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
C is the answer 100% stacked area chart: A 100% stacked area chart shows how the constituent parts of a whole have changed over time. The y axis scale is always 100%. Each area of colour represents one part of the whole. The parts are stacked up, usually vertically. (Found in Google)
Odidepse Selected: C üëç 1 N/A
B does not show referring to the visual diagram where you have different product category stacked up, question outlines 'You need to create a report that will contain the visual shown in the following exhibit.', that is clearly menat for 100% stacked area chart. Cannot be B line chart as per the exhibited visual shown which is stacked category..
namuuu Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
The report requires a visual that shows how Sales changes over time (by quarter). A line chart is the most appropriate choice because: Purpose of a Line Chart: A line chart is ideal for visualizing trends and patterns over a continuous dimension, such as time (Quarter in this case). It displays the progression of values (e.g., Sales) across sequential periods. No Additional DAX Measures Required: Since the DAX measure already sums the Sales column, the line chart can directly use the measure for plotting the aggregated sales values against the Quarter field.
Question 309
ID: 154497
HOTSPOT - You use Power Query Editor to review a query that contains a column named Country. You need to view the following information in the Data preview view for the Country column: ‚Ä¢ The percentage of values that contain errors. ‚Ä¢ The count of empty values. What should you enable? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Pey1nkh üëç 15 N/A
Error Percentage : Column quality Count of Zero : Column Profile (Zero Percentage : Column Quality)
f133b89 üëç 7 N/A
Both Answers are Column Quality Column Quality: The Column quality feature in Power Query provides a visual summary of the column data, including: The percentage of valid values. The percentage of error values. The percentage of empty (null) values. This is exactly what you need to see both the percentage of errors and the count of empty values. Column Profile: The Column profile provides a statistical overview of the data, such as distinct values, unique values, and value distribution. While useful, it does not specifically display the percentage of errors or count of empty values. Column Distribution: The Column distribution feature shows the frequency distribution of values in the column as a bar chart. It is not used for viewing errors or empty values.
santhosh28 üëç 5 N/A
Tested: Column Quality Column Profile
be79ac3 üëç 3 N/A
Quality - as it is a % Profile - as it counts
57fa092 üëç 2 N/A
after review, i think , column quality and column profile
Jasmine121 üëç 2 N/A
quality/profile one for percentage, one for counts
57fa092 üëç 2 N/A
Both should be Column Quality
Zakzouk23 üëç 1 N/A
chatGPT : The correct answer is Column quality because it shows a visual summary of the column‚Äôs data, including the percentage of valid, error, and empty values. Although it primarily displays percentages, when you hover over the empty or error segments, a tooltip appears showing both the percentage and the actual count of values. Therefore, Column quality allows you to view both the percentage of values with errors and the count of empty values.
Jasmine121 üëç 1 N/A
They are Quality and Profile.
omath üëç 1 N/A
1. To view the percentage of values that contain errors ‚Üí Column quality 2 To view the count of empty values ‚Üí Column quality * Column quality: - Displays valid, error, and empty percentages for each column. - This is where you see the percentage of errors and the count of empty values. * Column profile: - Provides detailed statistics (min, max, average, distinct count, etc.). - Great for numeric profiling, but not for error/empty percentages.
Question 310
ID: 155278
DRAG DROP - You have a Power BI semantic model that contains a table. You need to create a Power BI report page that contains two visuals that meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Visual 1: Displays the distribution of hierarchical data ‚Ä¢ Visual 2: Search and then filter by values Which type should you choose for each visual? To answer, drag the appropriate visual types to the correct visuals. Each visual type may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Odidepse üëç 8 N/A
Presented answer is correct - Treemap is for hierarchical data and slicer is for filtering
omath üëç 2 N/A
Visual 1 ‚Üí Treemap - A Treemap is designed for exactly this purpose. - It shows hierarchical data as nested rectangles, where the size of each rectangle represents its proportion of the whole. - This makes it ideal for visualizing the distribution of categories and subcategories. Visual 2 ‚Üí Slicer - A Slicer is the canonical choice. - It allows users to filter report data interactively. - Slicers include a search box, so users can quickly find and filter by specific values. - This matches the requirement to ‚Äúsearch and then filter by values.‚Äù
f83734b üëç 2 N/A
Treemap Slicer
Question 311
ID: 156044
You have a Power BI report that contains a bar chart. The bar chart displays sales by country. You need to ensure that a summary of the data shown on the bar chart is accessible by using a screen reader. What should you configure on the bar chart?

Options

  • A. conditional formatting
  • B. alt text
  • C. the tab order
  • D. the layer order

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
EdExamTopics Selected: B üëç 3 N/A
Alt text (alternative text) provides a textual description of the visual content, which can be read by screen readers.
SylUK üëç 2 N/A
"Alt text" refers to a textual description added to an image that explains its content for users with visual impairments who rely on screen readers, while "tab order" defines the sequence in which interactive elements on a webpage are navigated using the keyboard's tab key, ensuring a logical flow for users to access information.
omath Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: B. alt text * Explanation: - Adding alt text allows you to provide a written summary of the chart‚Äôs insights. - Screen readers will read this description aloud, making the chart accessible.
SylUK Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
The answer is B : alt text
b2775a4 Selected: B üëç 1 N/A
Alt text (alternative text) is used to provide a textual description of the visual content for users relying on screen readers. In this case, configuring alt text ensures that a summary of the bar chart (e.g., ‚ÄúSales by country‚Äù) can be read out by a screen reader, making the data accessible.
Question 312
ID: 156150
HOTSPOT - You use Power Query Editor to review the query shown in the following exhibit. Each Region value appears only on the row where it first occurred. Each subsequent occurrence of the Region value is blank. You need to ensure that every row contains the correct non-blank value. The solution must minimize development effort. Which column should you select, and which action should you perform on the column? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
b2775a4 üëç 11 N/A
Region/Fill down The Fill Down action in Power Query propagates the last non-blank value downward into subsequent blank cells within the same column. This ensures that all blank rows in the ‚ÄúRegion‚Äù column are filled with the correct value from the previous row where the region was specified.
omath üëç 2 N/A
* Answer: 1. Column: Region 2. Action: Fill down * Explanation: In Power Query, when you import data from sources like Excel pivot tables or grouped reports, it‚Äôs common to see a categorical column (like Region) populated only on the first row of each group, with the subsequent rows left blank. To fix this so that every row contains the correct Region value, you use the Fill Down transformation: - Select the Region column ‚Üí because that‚Äôs the column with missing values after the first row of each group. - Apply Fill Down ‚Üí this takes the last non-null value and fills it into the blank cells below until a new non-null value is encountered. This ensures that every row has the correct Region value, with minimal effort and no need for custom formulas.
Question 313
ID: 304704
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI report that contains the visual shown in the following exhibit. You plan to modify the visual by changing the column spacing and adding percent change labels as shown in the following exhibit. What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
omath üëç 2 N/A
1. To change the column spacing: Enable overlap for every series - In a clustered column chart, if you want the paired bars (Current Year vs Plan) to sit closer together, you don‚Äôt increase the gap‚Äîyou enable overlap. - This reduces the spacing between the series, making the comparison between Current Year and Plan more direct. - The option ‚ÄúEnable overlap for every series‚Äù ensures all series are aligned tightly, which matches the modified exhibit. 2. To add the percent change labels: Enable data labels for the Plan series - The exhibit shows the percent change labels only on the Plan bars (not on both series). - That‚Äôs why the correct choice is ‚ÄúEnable data labels for the Plan series‚Äù. - This way, the Plan bar acts as the reference, and the label shows the variance relative to it.
Lulu_2022 üëç 2 N/A
The given answers are correct.
Question 314
ID: 304723
DRAG DROP - You use Microsoft Power BI Desktop to preview a query in Power Query Editor. The query contains a column named Location Name. You need to identify the maximum length of each value in the Location Name column without changing the data. Which actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, drag the appropriate actions to the correct order. Each action may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
225401f üëç 9 N/A
I think Step 1 : Select the Location Name column Step 2 : Set Column Profiling based upon entire dataset Step 3 : From the View tab, select Column profile Step 4 : Group the value distribution by text length
Koriza üëç 2 N/A
Step 1 should be Column Profile not distribution as we need value distribution with ability to change 'group by'
omath üëç 1 N/A
1. Select the Location Name columna - You must first highlight the column you want to analyze. 2. Set Column profiling based on entire dataset - By default, Power Query only profiles the first 1,000 rows. - To ensure accuracy, go to View ‚Üí Column profiling ‚Üí Based on entire dataset. 3. From the Transform tab, select Extract ‚Üí Length - With the column selected, go to Transform ‚Üí Extract ‚Üí Length. - This creates a temporary column showing the number of characters in each row‚Äôs value. 4. From the View tab, select Column profile (or Column distribution) - Column distribution shows the frequency of lengths. - Column profile gives detailed statistics, including minimum, maximum, and average length. - Either will let you identify the maximum length of values in the column.
AmieM üëç 1 N/A
Step 1: You need to select the column you're analyzing. (Select the Location Name column) Step 2: Ensures Power Query analyzes all data, not just the first 1,000 rows. Step 3: Use Extract > Length to calculate the character length of each value. (From the Transform tab, select Extract, and then select Length.) Step 4: Column profile gives detailed statistics, including min/max length, for analysis purposes only. (From the View tab, select Column profile.)
Lulu_2022 üëç 1 N/A
‚úÖ Ordered Steps: 1. Select the Location Name column This ensures that Power Query focuses the profile and distribution stats on the correct column. 3. From the View tab, select ‚ÄúColumn profile‚Äù Displays detailed insights like min/max length, value distribution, and counts (nulls, errors, etc.). 4. Group the value distribution by text length This is a manual step: you can extract text length (Transform ‚Üí Extract ‚Üí Length), then group by that length column to see how many values share the same character count.
AmieM üëç 1 N/A
For Step 3 & 4, Column profile shows stats about the existing data ‚Äî min, max, count, etc. But it doesn‚Äôt calculate or display length of text values unless you‚Äôve first created a column with the length, hence why step 3 should be (From the Transform tab, select Extract, and then select Length.) before selecting column profile.
Question 315
ID: 304724
You plan to generate a line chart to visualize and compare the last six months of sales data for two departments. You need to increase the accessibility of the visual. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Configure a unique marker for each series.
  • B. Configure a distinct color for each series.
  • C. Replace long text with abbreviations and acronyms.
  • D. Move important information to a tooltip.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Koriza Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
nothing else helps with accessibility
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
A. Configure a unique marker for each series. Adding unique markers (e.g., circles, squares, triangles) to each line ensures that users can differentiate the series even if they cannot distinguish the colors. This is a recommended accessibility best practice: never rely on color alone to convey meaning. To make a line chart comparing two departments‚Äô sales over six months accessible, the best solution is to configure a unique marker for each series. This ensures that all users, including those with color vision deficiencies, can interpret the chart correctly.
21ad543 Selected: D üëç 1 N/A
I would have guessed D because displaying information explicitly seems like more accessibility than unique markers. But LuLu's comment seems valid as well.
Lulu_2022 Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
orrect answer: A. Configure a unique marker for each series üß† Why this improves accessibility: Using unique markers (like circles, squares, triangles) for each line in a chart helps users ‚Äî especially those with color vision deficiency ‚Äî distinguish between data series without relying on color alone. This is a key principle of accessible design: don‚Äôt use color as the only means of conveying information. Markers provide a shape-based cue, making the chart easier to interpret for users with protanopia, deuteranopia, or tritanopia.
225401f Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
correct answer
21ad543 üëç 1 N/A
Based off Gemini, A is the correct answer. Unique Marker.

Question 318
ID: 304744
HOTSPOT - You have the Performance analyzer results shown in the following exhibit. Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
a2c7cd3 üëç 3 N/A
Both are August 2024 Active User %
0c2d840 üëç 2 N/A
Both are August 2024 Active User % See this https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-performance-analyzer "Other - This is the time required by the visual for preparing queries, waiting for other visuals to complete, or performing other background processing.". So Other is the time spent where the visual waits for other visuals. "August 2024 Active User %" has the longest "Other" time.
BKel üëç 2 N/A
Should it not be Exec Sum Selected as this visual has to wait the longest to load?
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. August 2024 Active User %. 2. August 2024 Active User % * Explanation: When interpreting Performance Analyzer results in Power BI, you look at the Duration breakdown for each visual: - Total duration = DAX query time + Visual display time + Other. - The slowest visual is the one with the largest total duration. - The ‚ÄúOther‚Äù time represents how long a visual is waiting for other visuals or background processes to complete. From the exhibit: - Mobility Button, Adoption Button, Usage Button, Exec Sum Selected all load in ~172‚Äì176 ms. - August 2024 Active User % takes 474 ms total, which is significantly slower. - Breakdown: DAX query = 12 ms, Visual display = 177 ms, Other = 286 ms. - The large ‚ÄúOther‚Äù time indicates it is waiting the longest for other visuals.
Question 319
ID: 154485
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1. You need to create a measure that will display the sales result for all blue units. The solution must maintain the existing filter context. How should you complete the DAX expression? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Odidepse üëç 19 N/A
I would go for CALCULATE and KEEPFILTERS. CALCULATE evaluates a single expression (like [Sales]) within a modified filter context. In this scenario case, you want to filter the 'Unit'[Color] to "blue" while maintaining the existing filter context. CALCULATETABLE would return a table, which would then need to be aggregated further (e.g., using SUMX), making it less direct and has a layer of complexity. Second one , use KEEPFILTERS is the most appropriate for ensuring that the filter for blue is added to the existing context without overriding it.
omath üëç 2 N/A
* Answer: 1. CALCULATE 2. KEEPFILTERS * Explanation: - CALCULATE: Changes the filter context for the measure. - KEEPFILTERS: Ensures that the "blue" filter is applied in addition to any existing filters (instead of overriding them). - Without KEEPFILTERS, the filter on 'Unit'[Color] would replace any existing filter context on Color. With it, you‚Äôre narrowing down to "blue" while still respecting other slicers/filters.
Mkymp üëç 2 N/A
CALCULATETABLE is invalid here because: It returns a table, not a single value Measures can‚Äôt return a table // Sales = ... ``That means you need a **scalar value** like `SUM`, `COUNT`, etc. to be returned. - You're modifying the context to only include rows where `'Unit'[Color] = "blue"` - You want to sum up sales ‚Äî i.e., return a number So you use: ```dax CALCULATE ([Sales], KEEPFILTERS('Unit'[Color] = "blue")) That would be my answer.
fehler üëç 2 N/A
Sales_Blue_Units = CALCULATE( SUM(Sales[SalesAmount]), KEEPFILTERS(Products[Color] = "Blue") ) So in this case I believe we need to assume SUM is present, because after "=" should be CALCULATE
Jasmine121 üëç 1 N/A
should be calculatetable()
SylUK üëç 1 N/A
Look at the syntax structure it is CALCUTETABLE which can by applied here because it evaluates a table within a modified filter context. Therefore the answers are CALCULATETABLE and KEEPFILTERS.
Question 320
ID: 154486
You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that runs in Import storage mode. You need to reduce the size of Model1. The solution must NOT increase report query response times. What should you do?

Options

  • A. Remove unnecessary columns.
  • B. Unpivot unnecessary columns.
  • C. Rename unnecessary columns.
  • D. Change Model1 to DirectQuery storage mode.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
Odidepse Selected: A üëç 4 N/A
Presented answer is correct, Removing unnecessary columns will directly reduce the model's size by eliminating data that isn't needed. This change won't affect query performance since the excluded data is not part of the model. The others B. Unpivot unnecessary columns: Increases model size by adding rows. C. Rename unnecessary columns: Doesn't reduce size, only changes labels. D. Change to DirectQuery: May reduce size but can slow down query performance.
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. Remove unnecessary columns. * Explanation: When working with Import storage mode, the VertiPaq engine compresses data into memory. The size of the model directly impacts refresh times, memory consumption, and query performance. - Remove unnecessary columns is the best practice for reducing model size without harming performance. Columns that are not used in visuals, relationships, calculations, or security roles should be removed. This is called vertical filtering and is one of Microsoft‚Äôs recommended data reduction techniques.
SylUK Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
the given answer is correct: A will reduce the amount of data in the model. D also will decrease the model size but it can be slower especially for complex queries as it needs to query the source each time. A- is the answer.
Question 321
ID: 154487
You have a Power BI semantic model named Model1 that runs in Import storage mode. You need to reduce the size of Model1. Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents a complete solution. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Options

  • A. Summarize the detail data.
  • B. Upgrade to Power BI premium.
  • C. Implement row-level security (RLS).
  • D. Optimize the column data types.
  • E. Change the active relationships between tables to inactive relationships.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
AD
Odidepse Selected: AD üëç 5 N/A
Presented answer is correct A. Summarize the detail data: Since Import mode loads the entire dataset into memory, reducing the amount of detail data (for example, aggregating granular data like daily sales into monthly or yearly totals) can significantly reduce the size of the model in memory. This approach helps minimize memory usage and improves query performance. D. Optimize the column data types: In Import mode, data is compressed and optimized by the VertiPaq storage engine. Using more efficient column data types reduces memory consumption and ensures better compression when the data is loaded into memory. For instance, using integer or decimal data types instead of string can help achieve better compression and optimize performance. link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/service-dataset-modes-understand
omath Selected: AD üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. Summarize the detail data - Aggregating data before loading (e.g., monthly totals instead of transaction-level detail) reduces the number of rows stored in the model. - This is one of Microsoft‚Äôs recommended data reduction techniques for Import models. - It can drastically shrink model size while still supporting reporting needs if detailed granularity isn‚Äôt required. D. Optimize the column data types - Changing columns from Text ‚Üí Whole Number / Date / Boolean reduces cardinality and improves compression. - For example, converting an OrderID stored as Text to Whole Number can reduce storage by up to 90%. - This is a best practice for lean, efficient models.
Question 322
ID: 156870
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model that contains three tables named Products, OrderHistory, and Date. The Products table is a dimension table that contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ ProductID ‚Ä¢ ProductName The OrderHistory table is a fact table that contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ OrderID ‚Ä¢ ProductID ‚Ä¢ OrderDate The Date table is a dimension table that contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Year ‚Ä¢ Date ‚Ä¢ Week ‚Ä¢ Month You need to define a relationship from Products to OrderHistory and from OrderHistory to Date. Which cardinality should you configure? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct answer is worth one point.
kai_data üëç 19 N/A
the second should be many-to-one
a530d13 üëç 3 N/A
Nothing in the question indicates that there is at most one order per day. If there is more than one order per day then "one" date in the Date table would map to "many" dates in the OrderHistory table
dkilkelly üëç 2 N/A
The given answer is incorrect. It should be one-to-many, and then many-to-one. Without additional information provided, it would be rational to assume that the fact table has many dates which would relate to a single date in the date dimension table.
e9747cd üëç 2 N/A
Yes second one is many to one
cambolambo üëç 1 N/A
Is the second one really many-to-one? I don't get how they don't even have the correct answer choice as an option.
889efe8 üëç 1 N/A
correct
4b88f2d üëç 1 N/A
ye, but second option tells on-to-one, and the same like first option is relationing dim table with fact table, so must be one-to-many too. Am I wrong?
Anloindian123 üëç 1 N/A
Given answer is correct. Dimension table is always the "one side", and fact table is always the "many side"
omath üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: 1. One-to-many 2. Many-to-one * Explanation: In a star schema, the fact table (OrderHistory) sits in the center, and the dimension tables (Products, Date) connect to it. - Products ‚Üí OrderHistory: Products[ProductID] is a dimension key with unique values. OrderHistory[ProductID] is a foreign key that can repeat many times (since many orders can reference the same product). - OrderHistory ‚Üí Date: Date[Date] is unique in the Date dimension (each calendar date appears once). OrderHistory[OrderDate] can repeat many times (many orders on the same date).
Lulu_2022 üëç 1 N/A
From Products to OrderHistory: Cardinality: One-to-Many Why: Each product in the Products table has a unique ProductID, and that ID appears multiple times in the OrderHistory table (one row per order). This is a classic dimension-to-fact relationship. ‚úÖ From Date to OrderHistory: Cardinality: One-to-Many Why: The Date table contains a unique list of dates, and OrderHistory[OrderDate] contains many rows per date. Again, this is a standard date dimension to fact relationship.
Question 323
ID: 156875
HOTSPOT - You have a Power BI semantic model that contains two tables named Sales and Forecast. Both tables contain a date column. You need to create a calculated table that will cover the range of dates in both tables. How should you complete the DAX expression? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Anloindian123 üëç 3 N/A
The answer is so half baked. There should be a MIN(MINX MINX), MAX (MAXX, MAXX)
omath üëç 2 N/A
* Answer: 1. CALENDAR 2. MINX 3. MAXX * Explanation: CALENDAR: Creates a contiguous date table between a start and end date. MINX (Sales, Sales[Date]): Finds the earliest date in the Sales table. MAXX (Forecast, Forecast[Date]): Finds the latest date in the Forecast table. Together, this ensures the calculated table spans the full range of dates across both Sales and Forecast. * Why not the others: CALENDARAUTO: Automatically scans all date columns in the model, but it may include unnecessary ranges and doesn‚Äôt explicitly guarantee alignment to just Sales + Forecast. DATEDIFF: Returns a scalar difference in time units, not a table of dates. COUNTX / SUMX: Aggregate iterators, not appropriate for defining date boundaries. MINX + MAXX are the canonical pair for defining date ranges.
ca63a55 üëç 2 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/es-es/dax/calendar-function-dax
Lulu_2022 üëç 1 N/A
DateRangeTable = CALENDAR( MIN(Sales[Date]), MAX(Forecast[Date]) ) CALENDAR(start, end): Returns a single-column table of dates from the start to the end date. MIN(Sales[Date]): Finds the earliest date in the Sales table. MAX(Forecast[Date]): Finds the latest date in the Forecast table. This ensures the resulting table spans the entire timeline needed to support both historical and forecasted data.
f83734b üëç 1 N/A
1. CALENDAR 2. MINX 3. MAXX
b92fc92 üëç 1 N/A
isn't it correct?
Question 324
ID: 305012
You have a Power BI model that contains a table named Expenses. The table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Date ‚Ä¢ Amount ‚Ä¢ Category ‚Ä¢ Expense ID ‚Ä¢ Employee ID Expenses are recorded by employees, and each expense has a unique expense ID. You need to create a DAX measure that will calculate the total amount of expenses. Which DAX expression should you use?

Options

  • A. Sum(‚ÄòExpenses‚Äô[Amount])
  • B. Max(‚ÄòExpenses‚Äô[Amount])
  • C. Sum(‚ÄòExpenses‚Äô[Expense ID])
  • D. Count(‚ÄòExpenses‚Äô[Amount])

Answer

Suggested Answer:
A
kay000001 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
A. Sum(‚ÄòExpenses‚Äô[Amount])
omath Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
* Answer: A. SUM('Expenses'[Amount]) * Explanation: - It adds up all values in the Amount column, giving you the total expenses. - This is the canonical way to create a base measure in Power BI. * Why not the others: B. MAX('Expenses'[Amount]) - This would return only the largest single expense amount, not the total. C. SUM('Expenses'[Expense ID]) - Expense ID is a unique identifier, not a numeric measure of cost. Summing IDs is meaningless. D. COUNT('Expenses'[Amount]) - This would return the number of expense rows, not the total expense value.
Question 325
ID: 80001
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution. After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen. You are modeling data by using Microsoft Power BI. Part of the data model is a large Microsoft SQL Server table named Order that has more than 100 million records. During the development process, you need to import a sample of the data from the Order table. Solution: From Power Query Editor, you import the table and then add a filter step to the query. Does this meet the goal?

Options

  • A. Yes
  • B. No

Answer

Suggested Answer:
B
simplex06 üëç 81 N/A
I agree with the answer. B. No
H_E_Z üëç 33 N/A
I think query folding can push the filter into the query so A yes
BiLearn üëç 28 N/A
A, should be correct. We have concept of Query Folding. If we apply the steps and it can be converted to Native Query then it will execute as is. By development process it might mean by building Power BI Report, the view might be production view and as it is having 100 Million record. We cannot update the view for Power BI development.
Denjarus üëç 18 N/A
B is correct. This will load the entire table in the first step when you import. Instead add a WHERE clause to the SQL statement
Remko_K üëç 5 N/A
Query folding is only possible when using Direct Query. However, the exercise states import, so query folding cannot be used and as a consequence the filter cannot be pushed into the query.
MTG_1 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Answer: A. Yes ‚úÖ Explanation: The goal is to import a sample of the data from a very large SQL Server table (100+ million records) during development ‚Äî not the full dataset. Why this solution works: Power Query Editor allows you to add a filter step to restrict the amount of data loaded (e.g., filtering on date, order ID, or top N rows). While this filtering happens after import, Power BI is smart enough to fold the filter back to SQL Server if query folding is supported, meaning only the filtered rows are pulled from the database. Query folding: If your filter step can be translated to SQL (like a WHERE clause), Power BI pushes it to SQL Server, making the data load efficient even with massive tables. Best Practice Tip: For better control, you could also: Use a SQL statement in the advanced options during import to fetch a subset directly (e.g., SELECT TOP 1000 * FROM Orders).
RRconnect Selected: B üëç 2 N/A
you can select the required data in the sql query itself instead of importing all data and then apply filter in power query
ee0625a Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
Filtering ensures that we select only a manageable number of rows such as 100, 000 that will help test what we want to analyze rather than having 100 million rows
SilBri_830 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
In Power Query Editor, when you add a filter step to the query, only the filtered subset of data is loaded into the Power BI model. This approach allows you to work with a smaller sample of the data during development while maintaining the ability to later remove or adjust the filter for the full dataset.
Curious236 Selected: A üëç 2 N/A
"During the development process, you need to import a sample of the data from the Order table.". This approach meets this goal thanks to query folding, as after the filtering step, the native query sent to the data source will be modified to import only the rows that meet the condition.
Question 326
ID: 80615
DRAG DROP - You are preparing a financial report in Power BI. You connect to the data stored in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet by using Power Query Editor as shown in the following exhibit. You need to prepare the data to support the following: ‚úë Visualizations that include all measures in the data over time ‚úë Year-over-year calculations for all the measures Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order. Select and Place:
ThariCD üëç 401 N/A

Hi guys, I am wondering how you can do the second step - Unpivot all columns other than "Measure"? There is no column called "Measure" unless you transpose or unpivot it. This is a much more serious problem than the problem with the last step in the transpose solution - being the failure of change data type of "Year" to date.
marcionlinerj üëç 3 N/A
I agree. Using the transpose solution, when changing the data type of the Year column to date, the date is incorrectly transformed. It doesn't happen when using this solution.
a2c7cd3 üëç 3 N/A
Consider the request: To create visualizations that include all measures in the data over time, you need a Year column, a column of all measures and a column for each measure's values. This allows you to use a line chart to effectively visualize the measures over time. Note that converting a Year value from text to date will result in an incorrect date. The correct approach is as follows: 1. Transpose the table. 2. Use the first row as headers. 3. Unpivot all columns other than "Measure" 4. Rename "Measure" to Year.
Taras_Navakhatska üëç 3 N/A
Why shouldn't? The titles should be on the top.
mghf61 üëç 3 N/A
1. Transpose the table 2. Use first row as headers 3. Rename the Measure column as Year 4. Change the data type of the Year column to Date. I tested this and worked
RichXP üëç 3 N/A
tried, this one is correct.

Otherwise, select No. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Dsbuff üëç 6 N/A
- Total sales by product by month in which the order was placed: This analysis requires the OrderDate, ProductID, and SalesAmount columns. The ShipDate column is not required for this analysis. - Quantities sold by product by day on which the order was placed: This analysis requires the OrderDate, ProductID, and SalesQuantity columns. Again, the ShipDate column is not necessary for this analysis. - Number of sales transactions by quarter in which the order was placed: This analysis requires the OrderDate and InvoiceNumber columns. The ShipDate column is not needed for determining the number of transactions by quarter. Therefore, ShipDate column is not needed. So the 3rd answer should be Yes.

Question 328
ID: 104354
You have a Power BI model that contains a table named Sales. The Sales table contains the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Order Line ID ‚Ä¢ Product ID ‚Ä¢ Unit Price ‚Ä¢ Order ID ‚Ä¢ Quantity Orders are uniquely identified by using the order ID and can have multiple order lines. Each order line within an order contains a different product ID. You need to write a DAX measure that counts the number of orders. Which formula should you use?

Options

  • A. Count('Sales'[Order ID])
  • B. CountA('Sales' [Order ID])
  • C. CountRows('Sales')
  • D. DistinctCount('Sales' [Order ID])

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
SanaCanada Selected: A üëç 45 N/A
Order only once but can have multiple line based of different procduct Order ID A000101....Product A Order ID A000101.....Product B Order ID A000101....Product C Order ID A000101....Product D Correct Answer only D No confusion, and no need to discuss further
Maria86 Selected: D üëç 41 N/A
"Orders are uniquely identified by using the order ID and can have multiple order lines" - I think the important statement is "and can have multiple order lines" which means that the order ID can appear more than once in the table if the order contains more than one products - so I think the answer is correct.

you had put A as selected answer

thanks there is no need for no confusion in my no thinking head
539d541 Selected: D üëç 4 N/A
D is correct. SanaCanada is a bit loco
Dani_eL Selected: D üëç 4 N/A
Count only supports :Numbers,Dates,Strings CountA also supports Boolean CountRows will return values depending on relatedtable if any else counts number of rows in table DistinctCount as it says "distinct" counts distinct values (same as sql select distinct statement) Answer is D
tienanbich Selected: D üëç 2 N/A
D is correct
lukelin08 Selected: D üëç 2 N/A

Question 329
ID: 104403
You have a Power BI data model that contains a table named Employees. The table has the following columns: ‚Ä¢ Employee Name ‚Ä¢ Email Address ‚Ä¢ Start Date ‚Ä¢ Job Title You are implementing dynamic row-level security (RLS). You need to create a table filter to meet the following requirements: ‚Ä¢ Users must see only their own employee data. ‚Ä¢ The DAX expression must work in both Power BI Desktop and the Power BI service. Which expression should you use?

Options

  • A. [Email Address] - USERNAME()
  • B. [Employee Name] - USERPRINCIPALNAME()
  • C. [Employee Name] = USERNAME()
  • D. [Email Address] = USERPRINCIPALNAME()

Answer

Suggested Answer:
D
jessiejay Selected: D üëç 32 N/A
Within Power BI Desktop, username() will return a user in the format of DOMAIN\User and userprincipalname() will return a user in the format of[email¬†protected]. Within the Power BI service, username() and userprincipalname() will both return the user's User Principal Name (UPN). This looks similar to an email address.
jiriz Selected: D üëç 10 N/A
username() has the format of DOMAIN\username userprincipalname() always returns the user in the format of their user principal name, like[email¬†protected]We want mail, so userprincipalname() is right
Usm_9 üëç 7 N/A
WAS ON THE EXAM 02 03 2024
VGG2001 Selected: D üëç 5 N/A
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TGgec9oP8oU this video explains it.
panic_attack üëç 5 N/A
This was on the exam on 22/2/2024 (:
tiagoms üëç 4 N/A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/enterprise/service-admin-rls
RazaTheLegend Selected: D üëç 4 N/A
To implement dynamic row-level security (RLS) on the Employees table, a table filter must be created. The table filter should be based on the user's email address or user principal name (UPN), as these are unique identifiers for each user. The DAX expression [Email Address] = USERPRINCIPALNAME() will filter the Employees table to only show rows where the Email Address column matches the UPN of the current user. This expression works in both Power BI Desktop and the Power BI service, and will ensure that each user only sees their own employee data.
Akhilesh_Maithani üëç 3 N/A
answer is right
1sourabhpatel1 üëç 3 N/A
Option C is incorrect because it checks for an exact match on the Employee Name column, which may not always be unique for each user.
HoneyBunny Selected: A üëç 1 N/A
To create dynamic row-level security (RLS) in Power BI that allows users to see only their own employee data, you can create a DAX expression using the USERNAME function. Here's the DAX expression you can use for the table filter: scss Copy code Employees[Email Address] = USERNAME() & "@contoso.com" Assuming that the domain for the email addresses is contoso.com, this expression filters the Employees table to show only the rows where the Email Address column matches the email address of the current user. The USERNAME() function returns the Windows account name of the current user in the format DOMAIN\Username. By concatenating the returned value with "@contoso.com", the DAX expression generates the email address of the current user that matches the email address in the Employees table. Note that to use this DAX expression, you need to configure row-level security in Power BI Desktop or the Power BI service. You can assign roles to users and apply filters based on the DAX expression for each role.
Question 330
ID: 104406
You have a Power BI data model that imports data from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. You use Power Query to load a query that contains both renamed and custom columns. Later, you attempt to reload the query and receive the following error message. Expression.Error: The column 'Category' of the table wasn't found. What are two possible causes of the error? Each correct answer presents a complete solution. NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

Options

  • A. The column was removed from the source file.
  • B. The column was renamed in the source file.
  • C. The file is no longer in the specified location.
  • D. The data type of the column was changed.

Answer

Suggested Answer:
AB
jiriz Selected: AB üëç 23 N/A
correct
Starvosxant üëç 20 N/A
All the questions of those who upvote this comment will be at this level of difficult on the exam üôèüôå
jabbarjutt üëç 5 N/A
bruh this isn't reddit, why are u even asking for upvotes here ?
Igetmyrole üëç 5 N/A
A & B are correct answers. A. If the column 'Category' was present in the source file when the query was initially loaded but has been removed from the sources file since then, you would encounter this error when attempting to reload the query. B. If the "Category" column in the source file was renamed after the query was initially loaded, power query wouldn't be able to find the column with the original name, resulting in the error.

Answer is correct

iplearing0123 üëç 3 N/A
